Sec. 2-121. - Committees established. 
    The following committees of the City of Oak Ridge North, Texas, are hereby created: 
(1)  The Community Affairs Committee. 
(Ord. No. 22-2014, § 4, 3-24-14) 
Sec. 2-122. - Duties. 
(a)  General duties . The committee(s) shall function in an advisory capacity only to the city council, and in such advisory capacity shall have the responsibilities and duties set forth in subsection 2-122(b), as well as any other functions and duties assigned by the city manager or as may be determined by city council. 
(b)  Specific duties . The committee(s) shall have the following responsibilities and duties: 
(1)  Community Affairs Committee . The committee shall coordinate and work in conjunction with the city manager or his/her designee to coordinate and promote the exchange of information related to neighborhood events and community issues of public interest; to investigate and assemble information regarding neighborhood events and community issues of public interest; to make constructive recommendations to the city council to study and recommend options for encouraging neighborhood events and addressing community issues of public interest; to facilitate and organize recognition of members of the community; to facilitate and organize recognition of new local businesses establishing within and existing local businesses already serving the community; to strongly focus on promoting social capital within the city by facilitating and organizing programs, events and activities that encourage community involvement; to identify and pursue funding opportunities from third-party sources. 
(Ord. No. 22-2014, § 4, 3-24-14) 
Sec. 2-123. - Membership; term of office; compensation of members. 
(a)  General membership and appointment . Each committee shall be composed of nine members, consisting of at least one city council member. The city council shall appoint the members of the committee(s) upon the recommendation of the mayor. 
(b)  Community Affairs Committee. 
(1)  Membership qualifications. Qualifications for membership to the Committee shall be at the discretion of the mayor and city council subject to the following requirements: 
a.  Up to two non-resident business owners may serve, and 
b.  Up to two representatives from any church or other faith-affiliated organization located within the city may serve, 
c.  All other committee members must be city residents. 
(2)  Appointment of members; term of office; compensation . The mayor shall select, subject to approval by the city council, the members of the committee, who shall serve in such capacities for a period of two years. The city council will initially appoint five committee members for three year terms and four committee members for two year terms. Vacancies for the unexpired period of service of any member whose position becomes vacant shall be filled by selection by the mayor, subject to approval by the city council. Newly selected members shall be installed at the earliest possible regular committee meeting or city council meeting after their selection. Compensation for members of the committee shall be as determined from time to time by the city council. 
(3)  Removal of members . Notwithstanding the term of office set forth in paragraph (b) above, members of the committee shall serve at the will and pleasure of the city council, and are subject to removal by the city council at any time, with or without cause, and shall have no expectation of continued service on the committee. A member who is absent from three consecutive meetings of the committee shall be deemed to be removed from the committee, subject to reappointment by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 22-2014, § 4, 3-24-14; Ord. No. 24-2016, § 2, 5-23-16) 
Sec. 2-124. - Officers. 
    The committee shall elect a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary from among its members, each of who shall serve in such capacities concurrent with their period of service. 
(Ord. No. 22-2014, § 4, 3-24-14) 
Sec. 2-125. - Procedures. 
(a)  Quorum and voting . Each member in attendance at a duly called and noticed meeting of the committee, including the chairman, vice-chairman and secretary, shall vote on every matter before the committee unless prohibited by applicable conflict of interest laws. All matters to be heard by the committee shall be considered by a minimum of five members, which shall be the quorum necessary for conducting a meeting. The concurring vote of a majority of the members in attendance shall be necessary for the passage of any motion. 
(b)  Rules . The following rules shall govern the committee: 
(1)  Meetings and records . The committee shall comply with all open meetings and open records laws, Chapters 551 and 552, Government Code, and shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member upon each question or, if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall be promptly filed in the office of the city secretary. 
(2)  Reports to city council . The committee shall report to the city council from time to time as directed by the city manager. 
(3)  Priorities and goals . The city council may set priorities or goals for the committee concerning its activities and the committee shall comply with any such priorities or goals. 
(Ord. No. 22-2014, § 4, 3-24-14) 
Sec. 2-126. - Fees. 
    Matters submitted for consideration by the committee shall not be accepted for filing unless the applicant shall have paid to the city appropriate filing fees in such amount as may be determined from time to time by city council. 
(Ord. No. 22-2014, § 4, 3-24-14) 
Secs. 2-127-2-136. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION 

Sec. 2-137. - Economic development corporation authorized. 
    The city council hereby grants authority for a nonprofit economic development corporation to be created and incorporated, with such development corporation to be known as the "Oak Ridge North Economic Development Corporation" (the "corporation"). 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-138. - Articles of incorporation and by-laws. 
    The city council hereby approves the articles of incorporation and bylaws of the corporation, a copy of which is attached as Exhibit A to the ordinance from which this section is derived and incorporated herein for all purposes. 
    It should be noted that attachment Exhibit A above is not set out at length herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-139. - Nonprofit corporation status. 
    The corporation is hereby designated as a duly constituted authority and instrumentality of the city and shall be authorized to act on behalf of the city for the specific public purposes as set forth in the Development Corporation Act of 1979 (the "Act") and governed by Sec. 4B of the Act; but the corporation is not intended to be and shall not be a political subdivision or a political corporation within the meaning of the Constitution and the laws of the State of Texas (the "state"), except as provided in the Act, and shall have all of the powers set forth in the Act. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-140. - Board of directors. 
    The affairs of the corporation shall be managed by a board of directors consisting of seven directors appointed by the city council for staggered two-year terms of office. Not less than two directors shall be members of the governing body of the city. No member of the board of the corporation may serve more than four continuous two-year terms. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-141. - Meetings. 
    The board of directors of the Oak Ridge North Economic Development Corporation shall conduct regularly scheduled meetings on the first Thursday of every month at 7:00 p.m. or as deemed necessary by the board of directors. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
DIVISION 8. - CODE OF ETHICS 

Sec. 2-142. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this Code the following words, terms, and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed thereto: 
    City employee. Any person employed by the city, including those individuals employed on a part-time basis. 
    City officer. Any person identified as an officer according to statute or as otherwise designated by city council. 
    City official. A city officer or city employee. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-143. - Code of ethics. 
    All city officials shall observe and comply with the city's code of ethics policy as established and adopted by ordinance and maintained as a matter of public records by city's the designated records management officer. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12; Ord. No. 61-2014, §§ 2, 3, 11-10-14) 
Sec. 2-144. - State laws governing conduct. 
(a)  Conflicts of interest. 
(1)  Pursuant to V.T.C.A. Local Government Code § 171.001 et seq., a local public official having a substantial interest in a business entity or piece of real property must file, before any vote or decision is made on any matter affecting the business entity or real property, an affidavit stating the nature and extent of the interest. The official must file the affidavit with the city secretary, and is required to abstain from any further participation in the matter if: (i) the proposed action would have a special economic effect on the business entity that is distinguishable from the effect on the public; or (ii) it is reasonably foreseeable that the action would have a special economic effect on the value of the real property which is distinguishable from its effect on the public. An exception to the abstention rule is provided in cases where a majority of members of the entity are likewise required to and do file affidavits. 
(2)  A substantial interest in a business entity exists when the official: (i) owns ten percent or more of the voting stock or shares of the business entity; or (ii) owns ten percent or more or $15,000.00 or more of the fair market value of the business entity; or (iii) has received from the business entity funds which exceed ten percent of the official's gross income for the prior year. 
(3)  A substantial interest in real property exists when the official has an equitable or legal interest in such property which has a fair market value of $2,500.00 or more. 
(4)  A local public official means a member of the city council or other official of the city, paid or unpaid, who exercises responsibilities which are more than advisory only. A business entity means any entity recognized by law. 
(5)  It is an offense for a local public official to act as a surety for a business entity that is contracting with the city, or to act as a surety on any official bond required of an officer of the city. [V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 171.003] 
(6)  A local public official is considered to have a substantial interest if a person related to the official in the first degree by consanguinity or affinity has a substantial interest. [V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §171.002(c)] 
(7)  The provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 171.001 et seq. are in addition to any other municipal charter provisions or municipal ordinances defining and prohibiting conflicts of interest. 
(b)  Bribery. It is unlawful for a city official to accept or agree to accept: (1) a benefit as consideration for a decision, opinion, recommendation, vote, or other exercise of discretion as a public servant; or (2) any benefit as consideration for a decision, vote, recommendation, or other exercise of official discretion in a judicial or administrative proceeding; or (3) any benefit as consideration for a violation of a duty imposed by law on a public servant. [V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 36.02] 
(c)  Gifts to public servants. 
(1)  It is unlawful for a city official to solicit, accept, or agree to accept any benefit from a person the official knows is subject to regulation, inspection, or investigation by the official or the city. [V.T.C.A., Penal Code §36.08(a)] 
(2)  In the event of litigation involving the city, it is unlawful for any city official to solicit, accept, or agree to accept any benefit from a person against whom the official knows litigation is pending or contemplated by the official or the city. [V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 36.08(c)] 
(3)  It is unlawful for a city official who exercises discretion in connection with contracts, purchases, payments, claims, or other pecuniary transactions of government to solicit, accept, or agree to accept any benefit from a person the official knows is interested in or likely to become interested in any contract, purchase, payment, claim, or transaction involving the exercise of his discretion. [V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 36.08(d)] 
(4)  It is unlawful for a city official who has judicial or administrative authority, is employed by or in a tribunal having judicial or administrative authority, or who participates in the enforcement of the tribunal's decision, to solicit, accept, or agree to accept any benefit from a person the official knows is interested in or likely to become interested in any matter before the official or tribunal. [V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 36.08(e)] 
(5)  Exceptions to gifts to public servants. The provisions of V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 36.08 described above, do not apply to (i) fees prescribed by law to be received by the public official or any other benefit to which the official is lawfully entitled and for which the official has given legitimate consideration; (ii) gifts or other benefits conferred on account of kinship or personal, professional, or business relationships independent of the official's status with the city; (iii) certain honorariums in consideration of legitimate services; (iv) benefits consisting of food, lodging, transportation, or entertainment accepted as a guest and reported as required by law; or (v) benefits for which statements must be filed pursuant to V.T.C.A., Election Code § 251.001 and V.T.C.A., Election Code § 251.002, if the benefit and source of any benefit exceeding $50.00 is reported and the benefit is used solely to defray expenses which accrue in the performance of duties or activities in connection with the office which are nonreimbursable by the city. [V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 36.10] 
(d)  Tampering with governmental records. It is unlawful for any person to knowingly make a false entry in, or false alteration of, a governmental record, or to make, present, or use any record, document, or thing with knowledge of its falsity with the intent that it be taken as a genuine governmental record, or to intentionally destroy, conceal, remove, or otherwise impair the verity, legibility, or availability of a governmental record. [V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 37.10] 
(e)  Impersonating public servant. It is unlawful for any person to impersonate a city official with intent to induce another to submit to his pretended official authority or to rely on his pretended official acts. [V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 37.11] 
(f)  Misuse of official information. It is unlawful for a city official, in reliance on information to which he has access as a result of his office and which has not been made public, to acquire or aid another in acquiring a pecuniary interest in any property, transaction, or enterprise that may be affected by the information or to speculate or aid another in speculating on the basis of the information. [V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 39.03] 
(g)  Disrupting meeting or procession. It is unlawful for any person, with intent to prevent or disrupt a lawful meeting, to obstruct or interfere with the meeting by physical action or verbal utterance. [V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.05] 
(h)  Official oppression. It is unlawful for a city official to intentionally subject another to mistreatment or to arrest, detention, search, seizure, dispossession, assessment, or lien that he knows is unlawful, to intentionally deny or impede another in the exercise or enjoyment of any right, privilege, power, or immunity, knowing his conduct is unlawful, or to intentionally subject another to sexual harassment. [V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 39.03] 
(i)  Official misconduct. It is unlawful for a city official, with intent to obtain a benefit or with intent to harm another, to intentionally or knowingly violate a law relating to his office or employment or to misapply anything of value belonging to the government that has come into his custody or possession by virtue of his office or employment. [V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 39.02] 
    Official misconduct means intentional unlawful behavior relating to official duties by an officer entrusted with the administration of justice or the execution of the law. The term includes an intentional or corrupt failure, refusal, or neglect of an officer to perform a duty imposed on the officer by law. [V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 21.022(4)] 
(j)  Nepotism. It is unlawful for any city official to appoint, or vote for the appointment, to any office, employment or duty, of any person related within the second degree by affinity or within the third degree by consanguinity to the person so appointing or so voting, or to any other member of a board or governing body to which the person so voting or appointing may be a member, when the salary, fees, or compensation of such appointee is to be paid out of public funds. An exception is provided for persons who have been continuously employed in such office, employment or duty for the following periods prior to the election or appointment, as applicable, of the officer or member related to such employee in the prohibited degree: (1) at least 30 days, if the officer or member is appointed; or (2) at least six months, if the officer or member is elected. When a person is allowed to continue in an office, position, or duty because of an exception above, the officer who is related to such person in the prohibited degree shall not participate in the deliberation or voting upon the appointment, reappointment, employment, confirmation, reemployment, change in status, compensation, or dismissal of such person, if such action applies only to such person and is not taken with respect to a bona fide class or category of employees. [V.T.C.A., Government Code §§ 573.002, 573.041, 573.062] 
(k)  Disclosure of interest in property. It is unlawful for a city official, or a person elected, appointed, or employed as a city official but for which office such person has not yet qualified, to fail to make public disclosure of any legal or equitable interest he may have in property which is acquired with public funds, provided such official has actual notice of the acquisition or intended acquisition. The public disclosure required is the filing of an affidavit with the county clerks of all counties in which the property is located and wherein the official resides at least ten days prior to the acquisition. [V.T.C.A., Government Code §§ 553.001, 553.002, 553.003] 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-145. - Violations. 
(a)  Any city official violating any standard contained in section 2-143 above, entitled "Code of ethics," shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount not to exceed $500.00. Each day a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Penalties for violations of conduct described in section 2-108 above, entitled "State Laws Governing Conduct," are as set forth in the applicable statutory provision. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
ARTICLE III. - RECORDS AND INFORMATION MANAGEMENT[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, adopted February 11, 2013, repealed and reenacted article III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, article III pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, adopted November 19, 2012. 
State Law reference- Preservation and management of local government records, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 441.151 et seq.; Local Government Records Act, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 201.001 et seq.; municipal records management, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 203.021 et seq. 

Sec. 2-146. - Definition of municipal records. 
    All documents, papers, letters, books, maps, photographs, sound or video recordings, microfilm, magnetic tape, electronic media, or other information recording media, regardless of physical form or characteristic and regardless of whether public access to them is open or restricted under the laws of the state, created or received by the city or any of its officers or employees pursuant to law or in the transaction of public business are hereby declared to be the records of the city and shall be created, maintained, and disposed of in accordance with the provisions of this article or procedures authorized by it and in no other manner. 
(Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 2-147. - Additional definitions. 
    Department head means the person who by ordinance or administrative policy is in charge of an office of the city that creates or receives records. 
    Essential record means any record of the city necessary to the resumption or continuation of its operations in an emergency or disaster, to the recreation of its legal and financial status, or to the protection and fulfillment of obligations to the people of the state. 
    Permanent record means any record of the city for which the retention period on a records control schedule is given as permanent. 
    Records control schedule means a document prepared by or under the authority of the records manager listing the records maintained by the city, their retention periods, and other records disposition information that the records management program may require. 
    Records custodians mean the persons designated under section 2-153. 
    Records management means the application of management techniques to the creation, use, maintenance, retention, preservation, and disposal of records for the purposes of reducing the costs and improving the efficiency of recordkeeping. The term includes the development of records control schedules, the management of filing and information retrieval systems, the protection of essential and permanent records, the economical and space-effective storage of inactive records, control over the creation and distribution of forms, reports, and correspondence, and the management of micrographics and electronic and other records storage systems. 
    Records manager means the person designated in section 2-150. 
    Records management plan means the plan developed under section 2-149. 
    Retention period means the minimum time that must pass after the creation, recording, or receipt of a record, or the fulfillment of certain actions associated with a record, before it is eligible for destruction. 
(Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 2-148. - Municipal records declared public property. 
    All municipal records as defined in section 2-147 are hereby declared to be the property of the city. No municipal official or employee has, by virtue of his or her position, any personal or property right to such records even though he or she may have developed or compiled them. The unauthorized destruction, removal from files, or use of such records is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 2-149. - Policy. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city to provide for efficient, economical, and effective controls over the creation, distribution, organization, maintenance, use, and disposition of all municipal records through a comprehensive system of integrated procedures for their management from creation to ultimate disposition, consistent with the requirements of the Texas Local Government Records Act and accepted records management practice. 
(Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 2-150. - Designation of records manager. 
    The city secretary, and the successive holders of said office, shall serve as records manager for the city. As provided by state law, each successive holder of the office shall file his or her name with the director and librarian of the Texas State Library within 30 days of the initial designation or of taking up the office, as applicable. In the event of the absence of the city secretary or vacancy in the office of the city secretary, the city manager shall serve in the capacity as records manager for the city. 
(Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 2-151. - Duties of records manager. 
    The records manager shall perform such duties and have such responsibilities as shall be from time to time provided for by the laws of the state, which may include the following: 
(1)  Administer the records management program and provide assistance to department heads in its implementation; 
(2)  Plan, formulate, and prescribe records disposition policies, systems, standards and procedures; 
(3)  In cooperation with department heads identify essential records and establish a disaster plan for each municipal office and department to ensure maximum availability of the records in order to re-establish operations quickly and with minimum disruption and expense; 
(4)  Develop procedures to ensure the permanent preservation of the historically valuable records of the city; 
(5)  Establish standards for filing and storage equipment and for recordkeeping supplies; 
(6)  Study the feasibility of and, if appropriate, establish a uniform filing system and a forms design and control system for the city; 
(7)  Provide records management advice and assistance to all municipal departments by preparation of a manual or manuals of procedure and policy and by on-site consultation; 
(8)  Monitor records retention schedules and administrative rules issued by the Texas State Library and Archives Commission to determine if the records management program and the municipality's records control schedules are in compliance with state regulations; 
(9)  Disseminate to department heads information concerning state laws and administrative rules relating to local government records; 
(10)  Instruct records custodians and other personnel in policies and procedures of the records management plan and their duties in the records management program; 
(11)  Direct records custodians or other personnel in the conduct of records inventories in preparation for the development of records control schedules as required by state law and this article; 
(12)  Ensure that the maintenance, preservation, microfilming, destruction, or other disposition of the records of the city are carried out in accordance with the policies and procedures of the records management program and the requirements of state law; 
(13)  Maintain records on the volume of records destroyed under approved records control schedules or through records destruction authorization requests, the volume of records microfilmed or stored electronically, and the estimated cost and space savings as the result of such disposal or disposition; and 
(14)  Bring to the attention of the city manager non-compliance by department heads or other municipal personnel with the policies and procedures of the records management program or the Local Government Records Act. 
(Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 2-152. - Duties and responsibilities of department heads. 
    In addition to other duties assigned in this article, department heads shall: 
(1)  Cooperate with the records manager in carrying out the policies and procedures established in the city for the efficient and economical management of records and in carrying out the requirements of this article; 
(2)  Adequately document the transaction of government business and the services, programs, and duties for which the department head and his or her staff are responsible; and 
(3)  Maintain the records in his or her care and carry out their preservation, microfilming, destruction, or other disposition only in accordance with the policies and procedures of the records management program of the city and the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 2-153. - Designation of records custodians. 
    Each department head shall designate a member of his or her staff to serve as records custodian for the implementation of the records management program in the department. If the records manager determines that in the best interests of the records management program more than one records custodian should be designated for a department, the department head shall designate the number of records custodians specified by the records manager. Persons designated as records custodians shall be thoroughly familiar with all the records created and maintained by the department. In the event of the resignation, retirement, dismissal, or removal by action of the department head of a person designated as a records custodian, the department head shall promptly designate another person to fill the vacancy. A department had may serve as records custodian for his or her department. 
(Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 2-154. - Duties and responsibilities of records custodians. 
    In addition to other duties assigned in this article, records custodians shall: 
(1)  Conduct or supervise the conduct of inventories of the records of the department in preparation for the development of records control schedules; 
(2)  In cooperation with the records manager coordinate and implement the policies and procedures of the records management program in their departments; and 
(3)  Disseminate information to department staff concerning the records management program. 
(Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 2-155. - Records control schedules to be developed; approval; filing with state. 
(a)  The records manager, in cooperation with department heads, shall prepare records control schedules on a department by department basis listing all records series created or received by the department and the retention period for each series. Records control schedules shall also contain such other information regarding the disposition of municipal records as the records management plan may require. 
(b)  Each records control schedule shall be monitored and amended as needed by the records manager on a regular basis to ensure that it is in compliance with records retention schedules issued by the state and that it continues to reflect the recordkeeping procedures and needs of the department and the records management program of the city. 
(c)  Before its adoption a records control schedule or amended schedule for a department must be approved by the department head and the records manager. 
(d)  Before its adoption a records control schedule must be submitted to and accepted for filing by the director and librarian as provided by state law. If a schedule is not accepted for filing, the schedule shall be amended to make it acceptable for filing. The records manager shall submit the records control schedules to the director and librarian. 
(Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 2-156. - Implementation of records control schedules; destruction of records under schedule. 
(a)  A records control schedule for a department that has been approved and adopted under section 2-155 shall be implemented by department heads and records custodians according to the policies and procedures of the records management plan. 
(b)  A record whose retention period has expired on a records control schedule shall be destroyed unless an open records request is pending on the record, the subject matter of the record is pertinent to a pending law suit, or the department head requests in writing to the records manager that the record be retained for an additional period. 
(c)  Prior to the destruction of a record under an approved records control schedule, authorization for the destruction must be obtained by the records manager from the records management committee. 
(Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 2-157. - Destruction of unscheduled records. 
    A record that has not yet been listed on an approved records control schedule may be destroyed if its destruction has been approved in the same manner as a record destroyed under an approved schedule and the records manager has submitted to and received back from the director and librarian an approved destruction authorization request. 
(Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 2-158. - Records center. 
    A records center, developed pursuant to the plan required by section 2-149, shall be under the direct control and supervision of the records manager. Policies and procedures regulating the operations and use of the records center shall be contained in the records management plan developed under section 2-149. 
(Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 2-159. - Micrographics. 
    Unless a micrographics program in a department is specifically exempted by order of the municipality, all microfilming of records will be centralized and under the direct supervision of the records manager. The records management plan will establish policies and procedures for the microfilming of municipal records, including policies to ensure that all microfilming is done in accordance with standards and procedures for the microfilming of local government records established in rules of the Texas State Library and Archives Commission. The plan will also establish criteria for determining the eligibility of records for microfilming, and protocols for ensuring that a microfilming program that is exempted from the centralized operation is, nevertheless, subject to periodic review by the records manager as to cost-effectiveness, administrative efficiency, and compliance with commission rules. 
(Ord. No. 09-2013, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Secs. 2-160-2-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MUNICIPAL COURT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-181-2-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OFFICERS 

Secs. 2-186. - Appointment and qualifications of judge. 
    The municipal court judge shall be appointed by the city council and shall have such qualifications and serve for a term of office as provided by V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 29, or other state law from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
State Law reference- Judge of the municipal court, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 29.004 et seq. 
Sec. 2-187. - Vacancy in office of judge. 
    The city council shall by appointment fill a vacancy in the office of municipal court judge for the remainder of the unexpired term of office only, as provided by V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 29. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
State Law reference- Vacancy, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 29.011. 
Sec. 2-188. - Appointment and status of temporary replacements for judge. 
(a)  To provide for the uninterrupted, orderly and efficient handling of the judicial functions of the municipal court, the city council shall appoint one or more persons, meeting the qualifications for the position, to sit for the regular municipal court judge when the judge is unavailable or temporarily unable to act. 
(b)  The temporary replacements appointed to sit for the regular judge shall serve when requested by the regular judge or the mayor. The temporary replacements so appointed shall not serve for a term of office, but shall hold their positions at the pleasure of the city council and are subject to removal by the city council at any time, with or without cause. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-189. - Appointment and qualifications of clerk. 
    The municipal court clerk shall be appointed by the city manager and shall have such qualifications as provided by V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 29, or other state law as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-190. - Compensation of judge and temporary replacements. 
    The municipal court judge and temporary replacements for the regular judge shall receive compensation for their services to the municipal court as determined from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-191. - Prosecuting attorneys. 
    The city council shall select qualified attorneys to prosecute cases before the municipal court. The attorneys selected shall hold their positions at the pleasure of the city council and are subject to removal by the city council at any time, with or without cause. Prosecuting attorneys shall serve when requested by the regular judge or the mayor. Prosecuting attorneys shall be compensated for their professional services to the municipal court as determined from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Secs. 2-192-2-197. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FEES 

Sec. 2-198. - Municipal court technology fee. 
(a)  Establishment of fund. Pursuant to and in accordance with Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.0172, there is hereby created and established a municipal court technology fund (the "fund"). The fund shall be maintained in an interest bearing account. The fund may be combined with the city's general revenue account if its contents, including all interest earned thereon, are identified and accounted for. 
(b)  Assessment and collection of fee; fixing amount. There is hereby established a municipal court technology fund fee (the "fee"), which shall be in the amount of $4.00. The fee shall be assessed and collected from each defendant for each conviction of a misdemeanor offense in the city's municipal court as a cost of court. A defendant shall be considered convicted if: 
(1)  A sentence is imposed on the defendant; 
(2)  The defendant is placed on community supervision, including deferred adjudication community supervision; or 
(3)  The court defers final disposition of the defendant's case. 
(c)  Effective date. The fee shall be collected for each conviction for an offense committed on or after December 12, 2000. Provided however, any such fee collected on or before the effective date hereinabove established is hereby ratified, approved, and confirmed. 
(d)  Collection; procedures. The clerk of the municipal court shall collect the fee and render same to the city treasurer, who shall deposit all fees collected into the fund. 
(e)  Designated use of the fund; administration. The fund shall be used only for financing the acquisition of technological enhancements for the municipal court of the city, including computer systems, computer networks, computer hardware, computer software, imaging systems, electronic kiosks; electronic ticker writers; or docket management systems. The fund shall be administered by, and shall be under the direction and supervision of, the city council. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-199. - Municipal court building security fee. 
    There is hereby established a municipal court building security fee. Each person convicted of a misdemeanor offense in municipal court shall pay a $3.00 courthouse security fee as a cost of court. All such costs of court which are collected shall be deposited in the municipal court building security fee fund and may be expended only for the purposes authorized by Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.017. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-200. - Notice to mayor and council required; contents. 
    The city shall never be liable for any claim for property damage or for personal injury, whether such personal injury results in death or not, unless the person damaged or injured, or someone in his behalf, or, if the injury results in death, the person who may have a cause of action under the law by reason of such death injury, shall within six months from the date the damage or injury was received give notice in writing to the mayor and city council of the following facts: 
(1)  The date and time when the injury or damage occurred and the place where the injured person or property was at the time when the injury was received. 
(2)  The nature of the damage or injury sustained. 
(3)  The apparent extent of the damage or injury sustained. 
(4)  A specific and detailed statement of how and under what circumstances the damage or injury occurred. 
(5)  The amount for which each claimant will settle. 
(6)  The actual place of residence of each claimant by street, number, city and state on the date the claim is presented. 
(7)  In the case of personal injury or death, the names and addresses of all persons who, according to the knowledge or information of the claimant, witnessed the happening of the injury or any part thereof, and the names of the doctors, if any, to whose care the injured person is committed. 
(8)  In the case of property damage, the location of the damaged property at the time the claim was submitted along with the names and addresses of all persons who witnessed the happening of the damage or any part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
State Law reference- Notice of claim, V.T.C.A., Civil Practice and Remedies Code § 101.101. 
Sec. 2-201. - Consideration of claim by council prerequisite to commencement of suit. 
    No suit of any nature whatsoever shall be instituted or maintained against the city unless the plaintiff therein shall aver and prove that previous to the filing of the original petition the plaintiff applied to the city council for redress, satisfaction, compensation or relief, as the case may be, and that the redress, satisfaction, compensation or relief was by vote of the city council refused. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
State Law reference- Commencement of suit, V.T.C.A., Civil Practice and Remedies Code § 101.102; settlement, V.T.C.A., Civil Practice and Remedies Code § 101.105. 
Sec. 2-202. - Service of notice. 
    All notices required by this article shall be effectuated by serving them upon the city secretary at the following location: City Hall, 27424 Robinson Road, Oak Ridge North, Texas, and all such notices shall be effective only when actually received in the office of the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-203. - Swearing to notice. 
    The written notice required under this article shall be sworn to by the person claiming the damage or injuries or by someone authorized by him to do so on his behalf. Failure to swear to the notice as required in this section shall not render the notice fatally defective, but failure to so verify the notice may be considered by the city council as a factor relating to the truth of the allegations and to the weight to be given to the allegations contained therein. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-204. - Waiver of requirements of article. 
    Neither the mayor, a city councilmember, nor any other officer or employee of the city shall have the authority to waive any of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-205. - Director of finance. 
(a)  Creation. Under and by the authority of the city council, hereby creates the position of director of finance for the city. The director of finance is not a municipal officer, but shall fulfill and perform all the duties and responsibilities of the treasurer in accordance with state law and at the direction of the city manager. 
(b)  Hiring. The director of finance shall be chosen by the city manager on the basis of qualifications with special reference to actual experience in or knowledge of accepted practices with respect to the duties of the position hereinafter set forth and as determined by the city manager. The director of finance shall be responsible to and report to the city manager and the mayor and city council. 
(c)  Removal. The director of finance shall serve at the will of the city council, and shall be subject to discharge at any time, with or without cause. It is specifically provided that no person appointed to the position of director of finance shall have any entitlement, contractual right, or property right in such position or to continued employment by the city except to the extent that a written contract between the director of finance and the city may so provide. 
(d)  Duties. The director of finance shall provide a variety of accounting services in regard to the financial operations of the city. These services include payroll, general ledger, budget process, annual financial audit and accounts payable. He or she shall exercise those duties as may from time to time be directed by the city manager or the city council. To that end, the director of finance shall: 
(1)  General ledger. 
a.  Prepare necessary journal entries for property tax receipts, end of month transfers, etc. 
b.  Assure all deposits are taken to bank in timely manner. 
c.  Maintain necessary cash balances in accounts by transferring money to/from TexPool. 
d.  Maintain detailed schedules on receivable and liability accounts. 
e.  Assist with fixed asset maintenance and accounting for depreciation. 
f.  Make interfund transfers as needed for property tax, PID assessments, capital improvements, etc. 
g.  Reconcile all bank accounts. 
h.  Verify and print all financial statements. 
(2)  Budget. 
a.  Prepare budget calendar. 
b.  Meet with city manager and department heads for budget input. 
c.  Meet with mayor and council in workshop(s). 
d.  Prepare final budget for mayor and council. 
e.  Prepare all reports necessary for setting tax rate. 
f.  After final budget is approved, send out memos to all employees with notifications of salary increases, etc. 
g.  Review yearly expenses and prepare budget amendments. 
(3)  Payroll. 
a.  Verify all hours entered into time clock program. 
b.  Review payroll reports for reasonableness. 
c.  Verify vacation/sick balances and update attendance calendar each pay period. 
d.  Prepare check request for TMRS deductions monthly. 
e.  Prepare check requests for all payroll deductions each pay period. 
(4)  Sales tax. 
a.  Request listing from comptroller's office periodically and verify city roster. 
b.  Verify documents received bi-monthly that lists of all new area businesses and sales tax jurisdictions. 
c.  Prepare monthly sales tax report. 
d.  Disburse funds to EDC monthly. 
(5)  Audit. 
a.  Schedule annual financial audit. 
b.  Prepare all necessary schedules and gather requested information for annual audit. 
c.  Prepare all necessary journal entries for government-wide financial statement presentation. 
d.  Assist audit firm during audit. 
e.  File audit report on Disclosure USA website for bondholders. 
f.  Prepare necessary information and schedules for Workman's Comp audit. 
(6)  Accounts payable. 
a.  Verify invoices received have proper documentation and have been signed by department heads. 
b.  Code expenses on all invoices, match with any receiving documents, obtain managerial approval and enter into A/P system. 
c.  Print checks, assure appropriate signatures, distribute, record and file them. 
d.  Type and record manual checks for minor expenditures. 
e.  Maintain log book of purchase orders. 
f.  Maintain vendor W-9 files and conflict of interest questionnaires. 
g.  Process forms 1099 and 1096 and calendar year end. 
h.  Complete credit applications for new vendors. 
(7)  Miscellaneous. 
a.  Set up new vendors in accounting software. 
b.  Prepare monthly statements for receivables including DD6, Wulfe Management. 
c.  Prepare monthly sales tax for tax collected on garbage; file and pay electronically. 
d.  Complete miscellaneous salary and benefits surveys and insurance re-rate surveys. 
e.  Assist with human resources tasks. 
f.  Prepare RFP's as required for banking, insurance, etc. 
g.  Prepare quarterly and annual investment reports for city and EDC. 
h.  Prepare miscellaneous analyses as required, i.e. employee insurance costs, W/S rates, property tax, sales tax, etc. 
i.  Prepare financial reports and budget for EDC. 
j.  Prepare PID assessment billings, collect and record payments and reimburse to VORG, LTD. 
k.  Formulate property tax refund schedule for SMCMUD homeowners, verify payment through county tax collector website. 
l.  Assure semi-annual bond payments are made prior to due dates. 
m.  Assure quarterly court state fees reports reconcile to general ledger amounts, pay fees electronically, prepare Omni check request based on state fees. 
n.  Work with bank in getting new check signer documents prepared when there is a change in personnel. 
o.  Keep city manager advised on financial matters. 
p.  Assure that accounting records comply to retention guidelines. 
(e)  Compensation. The director of finance is an exempt position and is exempt from overtime provisions for the Fair Labor Standards Act, and is not eligible for overtime for any hours worked beyond a normal work period. The director of finance will be salaried, which salary shall be set and determined by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 08-2013, §§ 1-5, 2-11-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-2013, §§ 1-5, adopted February 11, 2013, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as section 2-205 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 2-206-2-209. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FEES 

Sec. 2-210. - Schedule of fees. 
    The city shall maintain a schedule of fees with the designated records management officer reflecting all fees, charges, deposits and/or rates as may be determined from time to time by the city council and established by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-211. - Penalty for violations. 
    Whenever in this Code or in any other ordinance of the city, or in any rule, regulation or order promulgated by any officer or agency of the city under authority duly vested in him, her or it, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever the doing of an any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of such provision of this Code or any such ordinance, rule, regulation or order shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00; however a fine or penalty for violation of an ordinance, rule, regulation or order that governs fire safety, zoning, or public health or sanitation, including dumping of refuse, may not exceed $2,000.00. If the maximum penalty provided by this Code for any such offense is greater than the maximum penalty provided for the same or similar offense under the law of the state, the maximum penalty for such violation provided by the laws of the state shall be the maximum penalty under this Code. Except where otherwise provided, each day any violation of this Code or of any such ordinance, rule, regulation or order occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-212. - Culpable mental state. 
    A culpable mental state is not required for the commission of an offense under this Code unless the provision defining the conduct expressly requires a culpable mental state or the offense is one in which the fine exceeds $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Secs. 2-213-2-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PURCHASING 

Sec. 2-231. - Purchasing policy. 
    All city officials shall observe and comply with the city's purchasing policy as established and adopted by ordinance and maintained as a matter of public record by the city's designated records management officer. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Secs. 2-232-2-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - UNCLAIMED OR ABANDONED PERSONAL PROPERTY[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Certain signs prohibited, § 62-37. 
State Law reference- Abandonment of personal property, V.T.C.A., Property Code § 72.001 et seq.; abandoned or unclaimed property seized by a peace officer, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 18.17. 

Sec. 2-241. - Authority to dispose of property; applicability of article. 
    The city manager or his/her designee is hereby authorized, in the manner set out in this article, to dispose of all unclaimed or abandoned personal property in the city's possession which remains unclaimed or abandoned by the owner for a period of 30 days and which is not held as evidence to be used in any pending investigation or case and has not been ordered destroyed or returned to the person entitled to possession of such property by the proper court or magistrate; provided, however, this article shall not apply to the disposal of cash, automobiles, firearms, liquor, drugs, narcotics or any other controlled substance. The disposal of particular items, property or classes of property which are governed by specific statutes, including the disposition of property alleged to have been stolen, as governed by Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. ch. 47, shall not be affected by the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-242. - Notice to owner. 
(a)  The city shall mail a notice by certified mail to the last known address of the owner of personal property subject to this article, no sooner than the end of the 30-day period referenced in section 2-241. Such notice shall: 
(1)  Describe the property held; 
(2)  State that if the owner does not claim such property within six months from the date such notice is mailed that it will be sold by bid and the proceeds of the sale, after deducting the reasonable expenses of keeping and selling such property, will be placed in the city treasury; and 
(3)  Be signed by the city manager or his/her designee. 
(b)  If the owner or address of the owner of such property is unknown, then the notice to the owner shall be published once in a newspaper of general circulation in the county. Such published notice shall contain the same information as a notice by mail, and shall contain the name or title of the city's representative to whom inquiries or a response may be directed. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-243. - Sale. 
(a)  The sale of any personal property under this article shall be preceded by a notice published once at least 21 days prior to the date of such sale in a newspaper of general circulation in the county, stating: 
(1)  The description of the property; 
(2)  The name of the owner, if known; 
(3)  The date, place and time that such sale will occur; 
(4)  That written bids will be accepted; and 
(5)  The name or title of the city's representative to whom inquiries and bids may be directed. 
    Bids shall be opened as provided in the notice and read aloud. If any bids are considered insufficient then the property need not then be sold, and such bids may be declined, and the property reoffered for sale in the manner provided in this section. 
(b)  If no bids are received such property may be disposed of as provided in section 2-244. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-244. - Disposal without sale. 
(a)  The city manager or his/her designee is hereby authorized to dispose of property which has been offered for sale and for which no bids have been received and otherwise unsellable clothing, food and other items of personal property to charitable organizations, or to destroy such property if it is not useable. 
(b)  When it is determined by the city council to be appropriate, items of abandoned or unclaimed personal property may be given or donated to charitable organizations, to be used for charitable purposes; provided, however, such disposition of property shall be subject to the notice requirements of this article and shall not impair the right of the owner of such property to file a claim for the fair market value of the property in the same manner as if a sale were conducted under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-245. - Disposition of perishable property. 
    Perishable food or other perishable property will not be subject to the 30-day and six-month holding requirements nor the advertising for sale requirements of this article; provided, however, all other provisions of this article shall be complied with. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-246. - Receipts; reports to city council. 
    A receipt for all property disposed of by sale or otherwise under the provisions of this article shall be retained, and if property is sold the proceeds from such sales and such receipts shall be promptly delivered and accounted for to the director of finance. The city council shall be provided a prompt written report of all property disposed of by sale or otherwise under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 2-247. - Claim to proceeds of sale. 
    The owner of any property sold under the provisions of this article shall have the right, subject to providing the city with satisfactory proof of ownership, to file a written claim to the proceeds of such sale with the city council. If the claim is allowed by the city council, the director of finance shall remit to the owner such funds as were paid into the city treasury as proceeds of the sale, after deducting the reasonable expenses of keeping and selling such property. 
(Ord. No. 40-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 41-2012, § 1, adopted November 19, 2012, repealed and reenacted chapter 6 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, chapter 6, articles I and II, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 012-86, §§ 1-4, adopted December 10, 1986. 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 18; consuming alcoholic beverage on city park grounds, § 54-35; traffic and vehicles, ch. 78; zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference- Local regulation of alcoholic beverages, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code §§ 11.38, 61.36, 108.55, 109.31 et seq.; local option elections, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 251.01 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Alcoholic beverage sales prohibited near churches, public schools or public hospitals. 
(a)  The sale of alcoholic beverages by a dealer from a place of business located within 300 feet of a church, public or private school or public hospital is prohibited. 
(b)  The measurement of the distance between the place of business where alcoholic beverages are sold and the church or public hospital shall be along the property lines of the street fronts and from front door to front door, and in direct line across intersections. 
(c)  The measurement of the distance between the place of business where alcoholic beverages are sold and the private or public schools shall be in a direct line from the property line of the private or public school to the property line of the business, and a direct line across intersections. 
(Ord. No. 41-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 109.33. 
Secs. 6-2-6-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMITS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Local permit fee authorized, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 11.38. 

Sec. 6-26. - Definitions. 
    The terms "alcoholic beverage," "permit," "permittee" and "premises," contained in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 41-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Definitions, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 1.04; "premises" defined, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 11.49. 
Sec. 6-27. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in section 1-4. 
(Ord. No. 41-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
State Law reference- Penalty for violation of Alcoholic Beverage Code, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 1.05. 
Sec. 6-28. - Fee imposed; payment. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and there shall be collected by the city a fee equal to one-half of the state fee set from time to time by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code for each permit required and issued for premises located within the city pursuant to the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code, as amended. 
(b)  Such fee shall be due and payable from each permittee to the city at the time the state permit fee is due and payable to the state from each permittee, pursuant to the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 41-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
State Law reference- Specific alcoholic beverage permits, fees, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 12.01 et seq. 
Sec. 6-29. - Exemptions from fee. 
    The following are exempt from the fee authorized in this article: 
(1)  Agent's, airline beverage, passenger train beverage, industrial, carrier's, private carrier's, private club registration, local cartage, storage, and temporary wine and beer retailer's permits; 
(2)  A wine and beer retailer's permit issued for a dining, buffet or club car; and 
(3)  A mixed beverage permit during the three-year period following the issuance of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 41-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Chapter 10 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---
