ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means any living creature of whatever genus or species, excluding human beings. 
    Animal control authority means the city animal control officer with authority over the area where the animal is kept or a county sheriff in an area with no animal control office. 
    Animal control officer means the person appointed as the city animal control officer or his authorized designee or the police chief employed by the city if no other appointment is made by the city. 
    Cat means the domestic mammal felis catus commonly found in the environs of the city. 
    Collar means any collar constructed of nylon, leather, or similar material, specifically designed to be used for a dog. 
    Dangerous dog means a dog that: 
(1)  Makes an unprovoked attack on a person or another animal that causes bodily injury and occurs in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own; or 
(2)  Commits unprovoked acts in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own and those acts cause a person to reasonably believe that the dog will attack and cause bodily injury to that person or another animal. 
(3)  Secure enclosure means a fenced area or structure that is: 
a.  Locked; 
b.  Capable of preventing the entry of the general public, including children; 
c.  Capable of preventing the escape or release of a dog; 
d.  Clearly marked as containing a dangerous dog; and 
e.  In conformance with the requirements for enclosures established by the animal control authority. 
    Dog means the domestic mammal canis familiaris commonly found in the environs of the city. 
    Farm animal means any cow, bull, steer, swine, sheep, ostrich, goat, horse, donkey, or any other animal normally raised for profit whether such profit is from the slaughter, products, or by-products of such animal, regardless if said animal is actually raised for profit. 
    Play area means any area where equipment is present for the use and entertainment of children. 
    Poultry and fowl means any chicken, turkey, duck, geese, guinea fowl, hen, rooster, pheasant or any other animal normally raised for profit whether such profit is from the slaughter, products, or by-products of such animal, regardless if said animal is actually raised for profit. 
    Properly fitted means, with respect to a collar, a collar that measures the circumference of a dog's neck plus at least one inch. 
    Restraint means a chain, rope, tether, leash, cable, or other device that attaches a dog to a stationary object or trolley system. 
    Run-at-large means an animal, except for a cat, that is not confined within the owner's lot, tract, premises, or parcel of land or if confined on the owner's lot, tract, premises, or parcel of land, is not under the control of the owner, keeper, or agent by means of a leash, chain, rope, or cord not more than ten feet in length if a dog, or by means of a restraining device typically used for that animal if other than a dog. 
    Serious bodily injury means an injury characterized by severe bite wounds or serve ripping and tearing of muscle that would cause a reasonably prudent person to seek treatment from a medical professional and would require hospitalization without regard to whether the person actually sought medical treatment. 
    Wild and exotic animal means any mammal, amphibian, reptile, poultry or fowl which is of a species which is wild or exotic by nature, and of a species which, due to size, vicious nature, or other characteristic, is dangerous to human beings. 
    Such animals shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Lions; 
(2)  Tigers; 
(3)  Leopards; 
(4)  Cougars; 
(5)  Jaguars; 
(6)  Cheetahs; 
(7)  Mountain lion; 
(8)  Wildcats; 
(9)  Panthers; 
(10)  Bobcats; 
(11)  Bears; 
(12)  Wolves; 
(13)  Raccoons; 
(14)  Porcupines; 
(15)  Opossums; 
(16)  Armadillos; 
(17)  Skunks; 
(18)  Apes; 
(19)  Gorillas; 
(20)  Chimpanzees; 
(21)  Orangutans; 
(22)  Baboons; 
(23)  Monkeys; 
(24)  Foxes; 
(25)  Coyotes; 
(26)  Dingos; 
(27)  Hyenas; 
(28)  Jackals; 
(29)  Lynxes; 
(30)  Servals; 
(31)  Ocelots; 
(32)  Caracals; 
(33)  Ferrets; 
(34)  Elephants; 
(35)  Rhinoceroses; 
(36)  Alligators; 
(37)  Crocodiles; 
(38)  Caymans; 
(39)  All forms of poisonous or venomous reptiles; 
(40)  Non-venomous snakes that will grow to a length greater than four feet; 
(41)  Weasels, including the marten, wolverine, ferret, badger, otter, ermine, mink and mongoose; 
(42)  Any hybrid of any animal listed above; or 
(43)  Any other exotic, non-domesticated animal. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- "Animal" defined, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 821.001; definitions pertaining to dangerous dogs, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 822.041; definitions pertaining to rabies, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.002. 
Sec. 10-2. - Who constitutes owner. 
(a)  The owner of an animal shall be any person who has the right of control, the right to sell or otherwise deal with the animal, or if such person is a minor, then the legal guardian of the minor. If any animal makes its home upon any lot, tract, premises, parcel of land or improvements within the city, or is provided food or shelter, and no person claims to be the owner of the animal, such animal shall be presumed to be the property of any adult resident, inhabitant, person providing the animal with food or shelter, or person in possession of the lot, tract, premises, parcel of land or the improvements on such property where such animal is located. 
(b)  The owner of an animal shall comply with this chapter and may be prosecuted for any actions, inactions, or conduct of any animal owned. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-3. - Authority of the animal control officer. 
    The city may designate a qualified person to be the animal control officer, who shall be responsible for the enforcement of this chapter. The animal control officer is designated the local health rabies control authority to perform duties as specified in V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code ch. 826. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-4. - General cleanliness and nuisances. 
    The following are declared a public nuisance: 
(1)  Animal structures, facilities, cages, enclosures, and pens that are not constructed and maintained to ensure the health, safety, and well-being of the animal or the public. 
(2)  Animal structures, facilities, cages, enclosures, and pens not kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(3)  Offensive odors or noises that disturb the peace, comfort, repose, or tranquility of persons of ordinary sensibilities who reside or work in proximity to the location on which an animal is kept or housed. 
(4)  Conditions that breed or attract insects, attract potentially disease-carrying vermin, pose a condition that causes or is likely to cause disease or endanger or is likely to endanger the health, safety, and welfare of the public. 
(5)  Female animals which are in heat and not confined in a structure, facility, cage, enclosure, or pen in such a way that the female animal cannot come into breeding contact with a male animal except for planned breeding. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-5. - Inspections and seizure of animals. 
(a)  The owner of an animal, or any person, shall, upon the request of the city, permit inspection to the area in which an animal is kept or housed, so that a determination can be made as to whether or not such animal is being kept and housed in accordance with this chapter. 
(b)  The city may apply for a seizure warrant with the municipal court if the animal control officer has reason to believe that an animal has been or is being cruelly treated. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
State Law reference- Disposition of cruelly treated animals, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 821.021 et seq. 
Sec. 10-6. - Veterinary examinations. 
    The city's animal control officer may require a veterinary examination of an animal at any time there exists a reasonable basis to suspect such animal is ill, diseased, or likely to become ill or diseased. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-7. - Roadside sales. 
    No person shall sell, trade, barter, or give away any animal on any street, road, highway, alley, public right-of-way, parking lot, or at any such place visible from a public right-of-way in the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-8. - Running at large prohibited. 
    No animal, except a cat vaccinated as required by state law, shall run-at-large. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
State Law reference- Municipal ordinances to control rabies, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.015; restraint of dogs, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.033 et seq. 
Sec. 10-9. - Destruction of dangerous animal. 
    A police officer or animal control officer may destroy any animal that presents a clear and present danger to the public. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-10. - Seizure and disposition of animal-at-large. 
    An animal-at-large may be seized by the city. Upon seizure, the city shall turn the animal over to the county for housing and disposition, unless such animal presents a clear and present danger to the public in which case the animal may be destroyed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-11. - Unlawful discharge of excrement. 
    Animals shall not produce excrement on public or private property, not owned by the animal's owner. The owner of an animal that produces excrement on public or private property shall pay for the reasonable cost incurred by the affected owners of the property for the removal of any excrement. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-12. - Striking an animal with a motor vehicle. 
(a)  Any person who, as the operator of a motor vehicle, strikes a domesticated animal shall immediately stop and render aid or assistance as may be possible and shall immediately report such injury or death to law enforcement and the animal's owner, if such owner can be determined. 
(b)  Any person who, as the operator of a motor vehicle, strikes a non-domesticated or wild animal shall immediately report such injury or death to law enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-13. - Beekeeping. 
(a)  No person or entity shall keep, house, maintain, or allow the existence or colonization of bees that interfere with the peaceful enjoyment of adjacent property or which endanger the public. 
(b)  No person or entity shall keep, house, maintain, or allow the existence or colonization of more than three bee hives with such hives being contained in a box not larger than 14 inches by 12 inches square. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-14. - Keeping or housing of wild and exotic animals prohibited. 
(a)  The keeping or housing of wild or exotic animals is prohibited, except as provided by subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Keeping or housing of wild and exotic animals shall be allowed if the owner complies with all federal, state, and local laws and: 
(1)  Such animal is being treated in an animal hospital by a licensed Texas veterinarian; 
(2)  Such animal is kept at a public zoo that is accredited by a nationally recognized zoological association; 
(3)  Such animal is kept at a shelter operated by state or federally recognized humane agency for the purpose of its transfer to a refuge or sanctuary; 
(4)  Such animal is kept for medical research or teaching purposes at a medical school or licensed hospital by a university or college offering an accredited degree program; 
(5)  Such animal is in the possession of an airline, motor freight agency, rail freight agency, or other carrier, possessing proper bills of landing, and its possession in the city is incidental to transportation, provided that the animal is secured in an enclosure that will prevent escape; 
(6)  Such animal is in the possession of an animal trainer licensed by state or federal regulatory or oversight agencies; or 
(7)  Such animal has been permitted by the city to be kept or housed in the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-15. - Permit required for certain events. 
(a)  Any events that use wild or exotic animals and not defined by subsections 10-14(b)(1)-(6) above shall submit and special event permit application to the city and pay a permit fee as set forth by city council in a schedule of fees. 
(b)  Any person or entity hiring, employing, or using a petting zoo, shall submit a petting zoo application to city and pay a permit fee as set forth by city council in a schedule of fees. 
(c)  Before granting a permit under this section, the city shall determine whether the issuance of any such permit will negatively impact the health, safety, and general welfare of the public and the city may deny issuance of a permit based on those reasons. The city may place reasonable conditions, limitations, and restriction on the issuance of any permit. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-16. - Animals causing nuisances. 
(a)  The owner of any dog or cat which is a nuisance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. A dog or cat shall be a nuisance if it: 
(1)  Opens or overturns a closed garbage container; 
(2)  Causes the disturbance or interruption of a public function on public property that may injure or affect the public health or comfort; or 
(3)  Disturbs the peace of another property owner or the tenant of another property owner without their permission. 
(b)  Any peace officer, public health officer or animal control officer of the city is hereby authorized to seize and impound any dog or cat which, in the opinion of such officer, is a nuisance, or which is alleged to be a nuisance by formal complaint. 
(Ord. No. 27-2013, § 2, 5-13-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 27-2013, § 2, adopted May 13, 2013, repealed § 10-16 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 10-16 pertained to number of pets allowed and derived from Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, adopted Feb. 25, 2013. 
Sec. 10-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 27-2013, § 2, adopted May 13, 2013, repealed § 10-17, which pertained to permits for additional animals and derived from Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, adopted Feb. 25, 2013. 
Secs. 10-18-10-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - KEEPING OR HOUSING OF DOGS AND CATS 

Sec. 10-36. - Registration of dogs and cats. 
(a)  Registration required. 
(1)  Dog and cat owners shall, annually, submit a registration application to the city to register all dogs and cats over the age of four months kept or housed in the city. The owner shall pay the city a registration fee as set forth by city council in a schedule of fees. 
(2)  The registration application shall state the owner's name, address, and telephone number as well as the name, breed, color, sex, and rabies vaccination date and tag number of each dog and cat. The city may require additional information on the registration application. 
(b)  An owner shall submit a registration application to the city no later than the 30th day after the date the dog or cat is vaccinated against rabies, or no later than the 30th day after the date the dog or cat reaches four months of age, or no later than the 30th day after the date a dog or cat is acquired or brought into the city, whichever occurs first. 
(c)  This section does not apply to dogs or cats whose owners reside temporarily within the city for a period not to exceed two weeks, nor to dogs brought into the city for the purposes of participating in a dog show, nor to Seeing Eye dogs properly trained to assist blind persons when such dogs are actually being used by blind persons for the purposes of aiding them in going from place to place. The city may require the registration of a dog under this subsection if deemed necessary for the protection of the health, safety, and welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
State Law reference- Registration of dogs and cats by local governments, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.031 et seq. 
Sec. 10-37. - Tag and collar required. 
    Upon approval of the registration application, the city will provide a registration tag that the owner shall attach to the dog or cat's collar, which such collar shall be constantly worn, affixed, or attached to the animal. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-38. - Replacement registration tags. 
    If the registration tag is lost, stolen, or destroyed, the animal's owner shall submit a registration application to the city and receive a replacement registration tag. The owner shall pay a replacement registration fee to the city as set forth by city council in a schedule of fees. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-39. - Non-transferability of registration tags. 
    Registration tags are not transferable. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-40. - Denial or revocation of registration. 
(a)  Any person denied issuance of a registration shall have the right to an appeal. If the city denies a registration, the animal's owner may file a written appeal with the city secretary no later than the tenth day after the date the city denies the registration. The city council shall conduct a public hearing no later than the 30th day after the date a timely appeal is filed. 
(b)  The city may revoke a registration for violations of this chapter. If the city revokes a registration, the animal's owner may file a written appeal with the city secretary no later than the tenth day after the date the city sends notice of such revocation. The city may send notice of revocation by certified mail with return receipt requested to the owner, may hand deliver notice of revocation to the owner, or may post notice of revocation on the animal owner's property. The city council shall conduct a public hearing no later than the 30th day after the date a timely appeal is filed. 
(c)  If a registration is denied or revoked, the animal may not be kept or housed in the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-41. - Dogs in parks. 
(a)  All dogs in city parks shall be on a leash no longer than six feet. 
(b)  No dogs shall be permitted in any play area intended for the used and entertainment of children whether on a leash or not. 
(c)  No dogs shall be permitted to be on or within the boundaries of any public sport fields, including but not limited to the baseball field at Marilyn Edgar Park, whether on a leash or not. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13; Ord. No. 20-2018 , § 2, 8-27-18) 
Sec. 10-42. - Unlawful restraint of dog. 
(a)  An owner may not leave a dog outside and unattended by use of a restraint that unreasonably limits the dog's movement: 
(1)  Between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.; 
(2)  Within 500 feet of the premises of a school; or 
(3)  In the case of extreme weather conditions, including conditions in which: 
a.  The actual or effective outdoor temperature is below 32 degrees Fahrenheit; 
b.  A heat advisory has been issued by a local or state authority or the city; or 
c.  A hurricane, tropical storm, or tornado warning has been issued for the jurisdiction by the National Weather Service. 
(b)  In this section, a restraint unreasonably limits a dog's movement if the restraint: 
(1)  Uses a collar that is pinch-type, prong-type, or choke-type or that is not properly fitted to the dog; 
(2)  Is a length shorter than the greater of: 
a.  Five times the length of the dog, as measured from the tip of the dog's nose to the base of the dog's tail; or 
b.  Ten feet; 
(3)  Is in an unsafe condition; 
(4)  Causes injury to the dog; or 
(5)  Is placed directly around the dog's neck but design and placement does not allow the dog a reasonable and unobstructed range of motion without entanglement, and does not provide access to adequate shelter and clean wholesome water. 
(c)  No chain, rope, tether, leash, cable, or other device shall be attached to a dog which is attached to a stationary object or trolley system. 
(d)  Exceptions: 
(1)  A dog restrained in compliance with the requirements of a camping or recreational area as defined by federal, state or local authority or jurisdiction; 
(2)  A dog restrained for a reasonable period, not to exceed three hours in a 24-hour period, and no longer than is necessary for the owner to complete a temporary task that requires the dog to be restrained; 
(3)  A dog restrained while the owner is engaged in, or actively training for, an activity that is conducted pursuant to a valid license issued by this state if the activity for which the license is issued is associated with the use or presence of a dog; 
(4)  A dog restrained while the owner is engaged in conduct directly related to the business of shepherding or herding cattle or livestock; or 
(5)  A dog restrained while the owner is engaged in conduct directly related to the business of cultivating agricultural products, if the restraint is reasonably necessary for the safety of the dog. 
(e)  Enforcement. 
(1)  A peace officer or animal control officer who has probable cause to believe that an owner is violating this section shall provide the owner with a written statement of that fact. The statement must be signed by the officer and plainly state the date on which and the time at which the statement is provided to the owner. 
(2)  A person commits an offense if the person is provided a statement described by subsection (e)(1) of this section and fails to comply within 24 hours of the time the owner is provided the statement. 
(3)  If a person fails to comply with this section with respect to more than one dog, the person's conduct with respect to each dog constitutes a separate offense. 
(4)  If conduct constituting an offense under this section also constitutes an offense under any other law, the actor may be prosecuted under this section, the other law, or both. 
(5)  This section does not prohibit a person from walking a dog with a hand-held leash. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-43. - Dangerous dog. 
(a)  Requirements of an owner of a dangerous dog. 
(1)  Not later than the 30th day after a person learns that the person is the owner of a dangerous dog, the person shall: 
a.  Register the dangerous dog with the city's animal control authority; 
b.  Restrain the dangerous dog at all times on a leash in the immediate control of a person or in a secure enclosure; 
c.  Obtain liability insurance coverage or show financial responsibility in an amount of at least $100,000.00 to cover damages resulting from an attack by the dangerous dog causing bodily injury to a person or another animal and provide proof of the required liability insurance coverage or financial responsibility to the animal control authority for the area in which the dog is kept; and 
d.  Comply with an applicable city regulations on dangerous dogs. 
(b)  The owner of a dangerous dog who does not comply with subsection (a) of this section shall deliver the dog to the animal control authority not later than the 30th day after the owner learns that the dog is a dangerous dog. 
(c)  If, on application of any person, a justice court, county court, or the municipal court finds, after notice and hearing per subsection (j) of this section, that the owner of a dangerous dog has failed to comply with subsections (a) or (b) of this section, the court shall order the animal control authority to seize the dog and shall issue a warrant authorizing the seizure. The authority shall seize the dog or order its seizure and shall provide for the impoundment of the dog in secure and humane conditions. 
(d)  The owner shall pay any cost or fee assessed by the city related to the seizure, acceptance, impoundment, or destruction of the dog. Such fee shall be set by city council in a schedule of fees. 
(e)  The court shall order the animal control authority to humanely destroy the dog if the owner has not complied with subsection (a) of this section before the 11th day after the date on which the dog is seized or delivered to the authority. The court shall order the authority to return the dog to the owner if the owner complies with subsection (a) of this section before the 11th day after the date on which the dog is seized or delivered to the authority. 
(f)  The court may order the humane destruction of a dog if the owner of the dog has not been located before the 15th day after the seizure and impoundment of the dog. 
(g)  For purposes of this section, a person learns that the person is the owner of a dangerous dog when: 
(1)  The dog makes an unprovoked attack on a person or another animal that causes bodily injury and occurs in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own or the dog commits unprovoked acts in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own and those acts cause a person to reasonably believe that the dog will attack and cause bodily injury to that person or another animal; 
(2)  The owner receives notice that a justice court, county court, or municipal court has found that the dog is a dangerous dog per subsection (j) of this section; or 
(3)  The owner is informed by the animal control authority that the dog is a dangerous dog per subsection (h)(1) of this subsection. 
(h)  Determination that dog is dangerous. 
(1)  If a person reports an incident described by subsection (g)(1) of this section, the animal control authority may investigate the incident. If, after receiving the sworn statements of any witnesses, the animal control authority determines the dog is a dangerous dog, it shall notify the owner of that fact. 
(2)  An owner, not later than the 15th day after the date the owner is notified that a dog owned by the owner is a dangerous dog, may appeal the determination of the animal control authority to a justice, county, or municipal court of competent jurisdiction. An owner may appeal the decision of the justice, county, or municipal court in the same manner as appeal for other cases from the justice, county, or municipal court. 
(i)  Reporting of incident. 
(1)  A person may report an incident described by subsection (g)(1) of this section to the municipal court, justice court, or county court. The owner of the dog shall deliver the dog to the animal control authority not later than the fifth day after the date on which the owner receives notice that the report has been filed. The authority may provide for the impoundment of the dog in secure and humane conditions until the court orders the disposition of the dog. 
(2)  If the owner fails to deliver the dog as required by subsection (i)(1) of this section, the court shall order the animal control authority to seize the dog and shall issue a warrant authorizing the seizure. The authority shall seize the dog or order its seizure and shall provide for the impoundment of the dog in secure and humane conditions until the court orders the disposition of the dog. The owner shall pay any cost incurred in seizing the dog. 
(3)  The court shall determine, after notice and hearing per subsection (j) of this section, whether the dog is a dangerous dog. 
(4)  The court, after determining that the dog is a dangerous dog, may order the animal control authority to continue to impound the dangerous dog in secure and humane conditions until the court orders disposition of the dog and the dog is returned to the owner or ordered destroyed by the court. 
(5)  The owner shall pay a cost or fee assessed as set forth by the city council in a schedule of fees. 
(j)  Hearing. 
(1)  The court, on receiving a report of an incident under subsection (i) of this section or on application under subsection (c) of this section, shall set a time for a hearing to determine whether the dog is a dangerous dog or whether the owner of the dog has complied with specified requirements. The hearing must be held not later than the tenth day after the date on which the dog is seized or delivered. 
(2)  The court shall give written notice of the time and place of the hearing to: 
a.  The owner of the dog or the person from whom the dog was seized; and 
b.  The person who made the complaint. 
(3)  Any interested party, including the county or city attorney, is entitled to present evidence at the hearing. 
(4)  An owner or person filing the action may appeal the decision of the municipal court, justice court, or county court in the manner provided for the appeal of cases from the municipal, justice, or county court. 
(k)  Registration. 
(1)  The animal control authority shall annually register a dangerous dog if: 
a.  The owner presents proof of liability insurance or financial responsibility, as required by subsection (a)(1)c. of this section; 
b.  Presents current rabies vaccination of the dangerous dog; maintains a secure enclosure in which the dangerous dog will be kept; and 
c.  Pays an annual registration fee to the city as set forth by city council in a schedule of fees. 
(2)  The animal control authority shall provide to the owner registering a dangerous dog a registration tag. The owner must place the tag on the dog's collar. This tag shall be worn by the dog at all times. 
(3)  If an owner of a registered dangerous dog sells or moves the dog to a new address, the owner, not later than the 14th day after the date of the sale or move, shall notify the animal control authority for the area in which the new address is located. On presentation by the current owner of the dangerous dog's prior registration tag and payment of a fee to the city as set forth by city council in a schedule of fees, the animal control authority shall issue a new registration tag to be placed on the dangerous dog's collar. 
(4)  An owner of a registered dangerous dog shall notify the office in which the dangerous dog was registered of any attacks the dangerous dog makes on people. 
(l)  Violations. A person who owns or keeps custody or control of a dangerous dog commits an offense if the person fails to comply with applicable city regulations relating to dangerous dogs. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13; Ord. No. 27-2013, § 3, 5-13-13) 
State Law reference- Dangerous dogs, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 822.041 et seq. 
Sec. 10-44. - Seizure of a dog causing death or serious bodily injury to a person or another animal. 
(a)  A justice court, county court, or municipal court shall order the animal control authority to seize a dog and shall issue a warrant authorizing the seizure: 
(1)  On the sworn complaint of any person, including the county attorney, the city attorney, or a peace officer, that the dog has caused the death of or serious bodily injury to a person or another animal by attacking, biting, or mauling the person or animal; and 
(2)  On a showing of probable cause to believe that the dog caused the death of or serious bodily injury to the person or another animal as stated in the complaint. 
(b)  The animal control authority shall seize the dog or order its seizure and shall provide for the impoundment of the dog in secure and humane conditions until the court orders the disposition of the dog. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-45. - Hearing on dog causing death or serious bodily injury to a person or another animal. 
(a)  The court shall set a time for a hearing to determine whether the dog caused the death of or serious bodily injury to a person or another animal by attacking, biting, or mauling the person or another animal. The hearing must be held not later than the tenth day after the date on which the warrant is issued. 
(b)  The court shall give written notice of the time and place of the hearing to: 
(1)  The owner of the dog or the person from whom the dog was seized; and 
(2)  The person who made the complaint. 
(c)  Any interested party, including the county attorney or city attorney, is entitled to present evidence at the hearing. 
(d)  The court shall order the dog destroyed if the court finds that the dog caused the death of a person or another animal by attacking, biting, or mauling the person or another animal. If that finding is not made, the court shall order the dog released to: 
(1)  Its owner; 
(2)  The person from whom the dog was seized; or 
(3)  Any other person authorized to take possession of the dog. 
(e)  The court may order the dog destroyed if the court finds that the dog caused serious bodily injury to a person or another animal by attacking, biting, or mauling the person or another animal. If that finding is not made, the court shall order the dog released to: 
(1)  Its owner; 
(2)  The person from whom the dog was seized; or 
(3)  Any other person authorized to take possession of the dog. 
(f)  The court may not order the dog destroyed if the court finds that the dog caused the serious bodily injury to a person or another animal by attacking, biting, or mauling the person or another animal and: 
(1)  The dog was being used for the protection of a person or person's property, the attack, bite, or mauling occurred in an enclosure in which the dog was being kept, and: 
a.  The enclosure was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own and provided notice of the presence of a dog; and 
b.  The injured person was at least eight years of age, and was trespassing in the enclosure when the attack, bite, or mauling occurred. 
(2)  The dog was not being used for the protection of a person or person's property, the attack, bite, or mauling occurred in an enclosure in which the dog was being kept, and the injured person was at least eight years of age and was trespassing in the enclosure when the attack, bite, or mauling occurred. 
(3)  The attack, bite, or mauling occurred during an arrest or other action of a peace officer while the peace officer was using the dog for law enforcement purposes. 
(4)  The dog was defending a person from an assault or person's property from damage or theft by the injured person. 
(5)  The injured person was younger than eight years of age, the attack, bite, or mauling occurred in an enclosure in which the dog was being kept, and the enclosure was reasonably certain to keep a person younger than eight years of age from entering. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-46. - Dogs or coyotes that attack animals. 
(a)  A dog or coyote that is attacking, is about to attack, or has recently attacked livestock, domestic animals, or fowls may be killed by: 
(1)  Any person witnessing the attack; or 
(2)  The attacked animal's owner or a person acting on behalf of the owner if the owner or person has knowledge of the attack. 
(b)  A person who kills a dog or coyote as provided by this section is not liable for damages to the owner, keeper, or person in control of the dog or coyote. 
(c)  A person who discovers on the person's property a dog or coyote known or suspected of having killed farm animals, poultry or fowl, or domestic animals may detain or impound the dog or coyote and return it to its owner or deliver the dog or coyote to the animal control authority. The owner of the dog or coyote is liable for all costs incurred in the capture and care of the dog or coyote and all damage done by the dog or coyote. 
(d)  The owner, keeper, or person in control of a dog or coyote that is known to have attacked farm animals, poultry or fowl, or domestic animals shall control the dog or coyote by keeping and housing the animal in a secured enclosure and registering the animal with the city. 
(e)  A person is not required to acquire a hunting license to kill a dog or coyote under this section. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Secs. 10-47-10-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - KEEPING OR HOUSING OF POULTRY AND FOWL 

Sec. 10-71. - Poultry and fowl. 
(a)  No person shall keep or house poultry or fowl on any lot, tract, premises, or parcel of land less than one acre. 
(b)  A total of three poultry or fowl may be kept or housed on any lot, tract, premises, or parcel of land one acre or greater provided that each poultry or fowl shall have a minimum of ten square feet of ground area available within the enclosure described in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  Poultry or fowl shall be kept in a secure structure, facility, cage, pen or enclosure that is at least 50 feet from any residence or building used for human habitation when measured between the two closest points. 
(d)  The following entities are exempt from the provisions of this section: 
(1)  Governmental entities; 
(2)  Any exception allowed by section 10-14; 
(3)  Any permitted event allowed by section 10-15. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-72. - Exemption for small birds and parrots. 
(a)  Section 10-71 shall not apply to small birds such as parakeets, finches, macaws, canaries, or other such similar birds. 
(b)  Section 10-71 also shall not apply to parrots. 
(c)  The following entities are exempt from the provisions of this section: 
(1)  Governmental entities; 
(2)  Any exception allowed by section 10-14. 
(3)  Any permitted event allowed by section 10-15. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13; Ord. No. 27-2013, § 4, 5-13-13) 
Sec. 10-73. - Permit for additional small birds. 
    The city may issue a permit for the keeping of the numbers of small birds in excess of that provided in section 10-72. The city, however, shall not issue a permit unless there appears, as demonstrated by the application of the person requesting the permit, such conditions or circumstances necessitating the number of small birds sought. The city shall investigate the application including receiving input from adjacent property owners and may issue or deny the requested permit. The city shall specify conditions, limitations, and restrictions in the permit. If the city allows for the keeping or housing of more than three birds, the animal owner shall pay fee to the city in an amount set by city council in a schedule of fees for each bird over three. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Secs. 10-74-10-81. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FARM ANIMALS 

Sec. 10-82. - Farm animals. 
(a)  Swine. 
(1)  No person shall keep or house swine on any lot, tract, premise, or parcel of land less than three acres, except owners may keep or house one domesticated pig on any lot, tract, premise, or parcel of land less than three acres. 
(2)  For every lot, tract, premises, or parcel of land three acres or greater, one additional swine may be kept or housed for every half-acre over three acres. 
(3)  The swine shall be kept in a secure structure, facility, cage, enclosure, or pen that is at least 150 feet from any residence or building used for human habitation when measured between the two closest points and shall be located at least 50 feet from the property line, except the one domesticated pig, allowed by subsection (a)(1) of this section, shall be kept in the primary residential structure located on the lot, tract, premise, or parcel of land. 
(b)  All other farm animals. 
(1)  No person shall keep or house farm animals on any lot, tract, premise, or parcel of land less than three acres. 
(2)  For every lot, tract, premises, or parcel of land three acres or greater, one additional farm animal may be kept or housed for every half-acre over three acres. 
(3)  Farm animals shall be kept in a secure structure, facility, cage, enclose, or pen that is at least 50 feet from any residence or building used for human habitation when measured between the two closest points. 
(c)  The following entities are exempt from the provisions of this section: 
(1)  Governmental entities; 
(2)  Any exception allowed by section 10-14; 
(3)  Any permitted event allowed by section 10-15. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Secs. 10-83-10-98. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RABIES CONTROL AND QUARANTINE 

Sec. 10-99. - Rabies vaccinations of dogs and cats required. 
(a)  The owner of a dog or cat shall have the animal vaccinated against rabies by the time the animal is four months of age and at regular annual intervals thereafter. 
(b)  A veterinarian who vaccinates a dog or cat against rabies shall issue to the animal's owner a vaccination certificate. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
State Law reference- Vaccination of dogs and cats required, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.021 et seq. 
Sec. 10-100. - Exemptions. 
    Hospitals, clinics, and other premises operated by licensed veterinarians for the care and treatment of animals are exempt from the provisions of this article, except where expressly stated. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-101. - Reports of rabies. 
(a)  A person who knows of an animal bite or scratch to an individual that the person could reasonably foresee as capable of transmitting rabies, or who knows of an animal that the person suspects is rabid, shall report the incident or animal to the animal control officer of the county or city in which the person lives, in which the animal is located, or in which the exposure occurs. 
(b)  The report must include: 
(1)  The name and address of the victim and of the animal's owner, if known; and 
(2)  Any other information that may help in locating the victim or animal. 
(c)  The animal control officer shall investigate a report filed under this section. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-102. - Quarantine of animals. 
(a)  A veterinarian shall quarantine or test any animal that the animal control officer or veterinarian has probable cause to believe is rabid, may have been exposed to rabies, or may have exposed a person to rabies. 
(b)  An owner shall submit for quarantine an animal that: 
(1)  Is reported to be rabid or to have exposed an individual to rabies; or 
(2)  The owner knows or suspects is rabid or has exposed an individual to rabies. 
(c)  The owner shall submit the animal to the animal control officer of the county or municipality in which the exposure occurs. 
(d)  A veterinarian shall quarantine an animal that: 
(1)  Is in the possession of the veterinarian; and 
(2)  The veterinarian knows or suspects is rabid or has exposed an individual to rabies. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-103. - Release or disposition of quarantined animal. 
(a)  If a veterinarian determines that a quarantined animal does not show the clinical signs of rabies, the veterinarian shall release the animal to its owner when the quarantine period ends if: 
(1)  The owner has an unexpired rabies vaccination certificate for the animal; or 
(2)  The animal is vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian at the owner's expense. 
(b)  If a veterinarian determines that a quarantined animal shows the clinical signs of rabies, the veterinarian shall humanely destroy the animal. If an animal dies or is destroyed while in quarantine, the veterinarian shall remove the head or brain of the animal and submit it to the nearest department laboratory for testing. 
(c)  The owner of an animal that is quarantined under this chapter shall pay to the veterinarian or local rabies control authority the reasonable costs of the quarantine and disposition of the animal. The veterinarian or city may bring suit to collect those costs. 
(d)  The veterinarian or city may sell the animal and retain the proceeds or keep, grant, or destroy an animal if the owner or custodian does not take possession of the animal before the fourth day following the final day of the quarantine period. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-104. - Area rabies quarantine. 
(a)  If rabies is known to exist in an area, the city may declare an area rabies quarantine to prevent or contain a rabies epizootic. 
(b)  On the declaration that a quarantine exists, the city shall: 
(1)  Define the borders of the quarantine area; and 
(2)  Adopt permanent or emergency rules. 
(c)  The rules adopted under subsection (b)(2) may include conditions for the restraint of carnivorous animals and the transportation of carnivorous animals into and out of the quarantine area. 
(d)  The quarantine remains in effect until the 181st day after the date on which the last case of rabies is diagnosed in a dog, cat, or other animal species that caused the city to declare a quarantine, unless the city, by declaration, removes the quarantine before that date. 
(e)  No animal shall be taken into the streets or public rights-of-way during quarantine or taken or shipped to or from the city without receiving written permission from the animal control officer. 
(f)  Animal control officer may require all vaccinated animals restricted (leashing or confinement on enclosed premises) for 30 days after vaccination. During the quarantine period, the city is hereby authorized to provide for a program of mass immunization by the establishment of temporary emergency canine rabies vaccination clinics strategically located through the area impacted. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-105. - Adoption of strays restricted. 
    No animal shall be allowed to be adopted from any animal shelter during the period of rabies emergency quarantine, except by special authorization of the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Sec. 10-106. - Destruction and disposition of rabid animal. 
(a)  Animals bitten by a known rabid animal may be immediately destroyed by the owner or by the order of the city. 
(b)  If an animal with rabies or suspected rabies dies, the animal shall be disposed of by a licensed veterinarian. 
(Ord. No. 05-2013, § 2, 2-25-13) 
Chapter 14 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Building in newly annexed areas. 
(a)  In areas finally annexed into the city on or after August 1, 1998, the construction or placement of any residential or commercial building, as the term building is defined in the city's zoning ordinance, will be permitted in accordance with the terms of a bona fide, binding, written contract entered into by the owner of the property, upon which the building is to be located, prior to the date of final adoption of the applicable annexation ordinance. Prior to beginning any construction or placement activities, the owner of the property shall be required to provide to the city satisfactory evidence of the pre-existing, bona fide, binding contract, including, but not limited to: the construction or sales contract, copies of canceled down-payment or deposit checks, or other documents customarily executed in connection with such transactions, and the affidavits of the parties attesting that the statements, contract, and other documents submitted are true and correct. 
(b)  The property owner shall otherwise comply with the city's code of ordinances, including by way of example, the city's zoning ordinance and the flood damage prevention ordinance, as well as any other ordinance enforced by the city to protect the public health and safety, in connection with construction or placement of a residential or commercial building pursuant to a pre-existing contract, as provided in this section 14-1. This section 14-1 shall not be construed nor interpreted as a waiver or relaxation of the requirement that any construction or placement of a building in the city shall be undertaken so as not to create a nuisance nor constitute a danger to the health and safety of persons or property. 
(c)  For any building actually under construction (work having proceeded beyond site preparation or foundation earth work) on the effective date of annexation, no permit fee shall be charged for issuance of the required city permits. For protection of the public health and safety, the city shall have reasonable access for all inspections required by this Code, including the city's construction regulations, and the inspection fee usually charged for a city inspection shall be paid by the owner. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-2. - Municipal registration of contractors. 
(a)  All contractors engaged in construction activities must be registered with the city as a contractor. Each contractor must carry the minimum required amount of liability insurance as required by state law. The fees for such registration are outlined in the schedule of fees. 
(b)  Exceptions: 
(1)  Homeowners that have homestead exemption for the property they plan to perform construction activities. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Secs. 14-3-14-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-26. - Provisions applicable to all building codes. 
    Except as otherwise expressly provided, the provisions of this article apply to the administration and enforcement of both the residential and nonresidential building codes. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-27. - Application of technical codes. 
    The city has adopted separate technical codes covering the electrical, plumbing and mechanical components of building construction. To the extent there is any conflict between the provisions of such technical codes and the building codes adopted under this article, such technical codes shall apply and control over the more general building codes. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-28. - Permit procedures. 
(a)  The building inspection department is located at city hall, and permit application forms are available there. 
(b)  To obtain a building permit, the applicant shall submit an application form along with two complete sets of drawings for residential construction. One set shall be on a disk as a digital PDF file. Nonresidential construction shall be three complete sets of drawings. One set shall be on a disk as a digital PDF file. 
(c)  A complete set of drawings must include: 
(1)  A site survey showing proposed location of building site with the exception of interior remodels. Site surveys shall include the following information: 
a.  Recorded building setbacks; 
b.  The location of every existing and proposed building or structure on the site or lot; 
c.  The location of existing easements, storm sewers, natural drains, water lines, and the location of water and sewer connections; and 
d.  Except for one-family and two-family dwellings, the proposed location and access route for a commercial garbage collection container or containers that are sufficient in size and number to meet the disposal needs which may be reasonably anticipated upon the premises given the kind, character and density of the proposed development. 
(2)  Engineered foundation plans as determined by the building official. 
(3)  A floor plan which includes elevation. 
(d)  Due to the different characteristics of each building project, additional information may be required on the drawings as determined by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-29. - Additional conditions on building permits. 
(a)  Water and sewer service. A permit shall not be given by the building official for the construction of any building unless adequate information, approved by the public works director, is furnished showing adequate water and sewer service is available to the property or that suitable arrangements have been made for obtaining water and sewer service to the building site. The water and sewer lines, if not in existence, shall be extended at the owners' expense to cover the entire length of the property where future extensions are necessary to serve adjacent properties and/or for looping purposes. 
(b)  Elevation certificates. A permit shall not be given by the building official for the construction of, alteration to, or addition to, any building or structure unless elevation certificates are provided by the applicant for all properties located within, partially within, or near the flood hazard areas as referenced in chapter 42 of this Code. 
(c)  Floodplain areas. Within floodplain areas that are subject to a one percent or greater chance of flooding in any given year, each new building must be constructed so that the lowest floor elevation of the building is at least one foot above the base flood elevation. The base flood elevation is the surface elevation of floodwaters during a flood that has a one percent or greater chance of occurring in any given year. 
(d)  Zoning regulations. The city has adopted separate zoning regulations referenced in Appendix A of this Code. To the extent there is any conflict between the provisions of such zoning regulations and the building codes adopted under this article, the more stringent regulation or code provision shall apply. 
(e)  Commercial, business or industrial buildings shall be constructed on a concrete foundation, except where the building is required to be elevated to satisfy the floodplain or flood prone height limitations of chapter 42, article II, flood damage prevention, in which case the foundation at grade level shall be of concrete. 
(f)  Driveways and patio slabs shall be a minimum of four inches thick (the approach to the driveway shall be five and one-half inches minimum), with a minimum of six-inch by six-inch #10 welded wire mesh in the pour, over culverts. Expansion points shall be provided every 20 lineal feet, minimum. Approaches are to be scored to a depth of at least one inch, at front property lines. 
(g)  Any building hereinafter constructed, erected or otherwise established in zoning districts B-1, B-2, M-1, M-2 and I, except as otherwise provided in this article, shall: 
(1)  Be no less than 1,200 total square feet in area; 
(2)  Have permanent sewer and water connections; and 
(3)  Have a foundation constructed only of concrete, except as provided under chapter 42, article II, flood damage prevention, Code of Ordinances. 
(h)  Trailer, as defined under Appendix A, subsection 3(32), Code of Ordinances, and other temporary buildings shall not be used for commercial purposes, or incidental to commercial purposes in zoning districts B-1, B-2, M-1, M-2 and I, except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(1)  This subsection does not apply to the direct or incidental use of trailers and other temporary buildings for nonprofit, or other charitable purposes; 
(2)  This subsection does not apply to the direct or incidental use of trailers and other temporary buildings for construction of a permanent building that is not expressly prohibited under the provisions of this article; 
(3)  Trailers and other temporary buildings used for said construction shall be removed without undue delay after construction is completed; and 
(4)  Permanent water or sewer connections to said trailers and other temporary buildings are expressly prohibited. 
(i)  Accessory buildings, as defined under Appendix A, subsection 3(1), Code of Ordinances, are not prohibited. 
(j)  A building in zoning districts B-1, B-2, M-1, M-2 and I that is classified as a nonconforming use under Appendix A, subsection 3(26), Code of Ordinances, at the time this ordinance is enacted is not in violation of subsection 14-80(8)a. 
(k)  A building in zoning districts B-1, B-2, M-1, M-2 and I that is classified as a nonconforming use shall meet the requirements provided in subsection 14-30(8)a. before any structural alteration or alterations in the use, classification, or occupancy of said building is approved under the provisions of this Code. 
(l)  Parking lots. Grade level parking lots and parking spaces shall be paved with: 
(1)  Concrete: Minimum concrete slab thickness shall be five inches to 3,000 psi and reinforcement to 60,000 psi. 
a.  Minimum stabilized subgrade thickness shall be six inches. 
(2)  Asphalt: Minimum one and one-half-inch asphaltic concrete surface course. 
a.  Minimum six-inch limestone base. 
b.  Minimum six-inch stabilized subgrade. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-30. - Inspection procedures. 
(a)  After a permit is issued, the required inspections will be made within 72 hours of the building inspection department receiving notice. 
(b)  Due to the different characteristics of each building project, the building official shall determine the required inspections for each project. At a minimum, the required inspections as outlined in the international codes shall be performed. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-31. - Certificates of occupancy. 
(a)  Certificates of occupancy shall be issued as provided by the applicable building code. Certificates of occupancy that purport to give authority to violate or cancel the provisions of an applicable building code or other ordinance shall not be valid. The building official shall, in writing, suspend or revoke a certificate of occupancy that has been issued in error, or on the basis of incorrect information supplied, or where it is determined that the building or structure or portion thereof is in violation of an applicable building code or other ordinance. 
(b)  Certificates of occupancy shall not be issued unless proof can be provided to the building official showing an active account with the commercial garbage service company granted a franchise by the city. 
(c)  A temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued for a portion or portions of a building which may be safely occupied pending final completion of further construction pursuant to a valid building permit. No temporary or final certificate of occupancy shall be issued until all required fire protection systems have been installed, tested and approved. 
(d)  A certificate of occupancy expires if any of the following events occurs: 
(1)  There is a change in use or occupancy effecting all or any portion of a building; 
(2)  There is commenced without a permit any alteration, repair, or addition to the building for which a building permit is required; 
(3)  There is a change in ownership of a building, other than a one-family or two-family dwelling to which residential building code applies; or 
(4)  There is a change in tenants of a building, other than one-family or two-family dwelling to which residential building code applies. 
(e)  The owner of any building for which a certificate of occupancy shall have terminated shall, before further occupancy, apply to the building official for issuance of a new certificate of occupancy consistent with the proposed use of such building. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-32. - Commercial and residential building permit fees. 
(a)  The building permit fees applicable to the issuance of commercial building permits and residential permits shall be based upon the building valuation table as adopted by city council and shall be as set out in the schedule of fees. 
(b)  If the value of the proposed construction exceeds $1,000.00 or plans are required to be submitted, then a plan checking fee shall be paid to the building official at the time of submitting the plans and specifications for checking. The plan checking fee shall be equal to one-half of the building permit fee as set forth in subsection (a) of this section. The plan checking fee is in addition to the building permit fee. Plans will be reviewed and approved, or returned for correction in accordance with the comments provided by the building official. The initial plan checking fee shall cover the first submission and two subsequent submissions and reviews. If a fourth submission is necessary the submission must be accompanied by a new plan checking fee calculated as provided in this section. If a fifth submission is required, a fee equal to twice the ordinary fee must accompany the application. If a sixth or subsequent submission is necessary, a fee equal to three times the ordinary fee must accompany the submission. 
(c)  For every inspection for certificate of occupancy, reissuance of a certificate of occupancy or call back for reinspection, the fee shall be as set out in the schedule of fees. The fee for a temporary certificate of occupancy shall also be as set out in the schedule of fees. 
(d)  Where work for which a permit is required is started prior to obtaining a permit the fees specified by this section shall be doubled, but the payment of such double fee shall not relieve any persons from fully complying with the requirements of the applicable building code in the execution of the work, nor shall it relieve the person from any other penalties that may be applicable. 
(e)  Permits for electrical, mechanical, plumbing or other technical code work must be obtained in addition to the building permit. Technical code permit fees are established within those codes and must be paid in addition to the building permit fees. 
(f)  Permits for demolition without a building permit must be obtained prior to starting demolition. The fee for a demolition permit shall be as specified in the schedule of fees. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-33. - Inspection fees. 
    Inspection fees shall be as specified in the schedule of fees. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-34. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate a provision of this article, the codes adopted herein or any revisions thereto or fail to comply therewith, or with any of the requirements thereof, or who shall erect, construct, alter, demolish or move any building or structure, or have erected, constructed, altered, repaired, moved or demolished a building or structure, in violation of a detailed statement or drawing submitted and approved thereunder, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any such violation is committed or continued, and upon conviction of any such violation such person shall be punished as provided in section 1-4. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESIDENTIAL BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 14-36. - International Residential Code adopted. 
(a)  International Residential Code. The International Residential Code, 2009 Edition, as published by the International Code Council, a copy of which is attached hereto and made a part hereof for all purposes, an authentic copy of which has been filed with the city secretary, is hereby adopted and made a part of this Code of Ordinances. The adoption of the International Residential Code includes the adoption of all appendices to such code except Appendix F, Appendix L, and Appendix Q which are expressly not adopted. 
(b)  The International Residential Code does not apply to the installation and maintenance of electrical wiring and related components which shall instead be governed by the provisions of the National Electrical Code as adopted by article III of this chapter. 
(c)  The building official shall periodically review amendments to the 2009 International Residential Code as published by the International Code Council, and may recommend the adoption of such amendments to the city council. The building official may also recommend other local amendments to the International Residential Code. Local amendments to the International Residential Code shall be adopted by ordinance and shall control over any conflicting provisions of the International Residential Code. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-37. - Amendments to the International Residential Code. 
    The International Residential Code adopted in section 14-36 is amended as follows: 
(a)  Section R101.2. Scope, is hereby amended by the deletion of the exception for live/work units. 
(b)  Section R105.2. Work exempt from permit, is hereby amended by the deletion of the exempt work numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 9, and 10 under the subsection for "Building". 
(c)  Section R313 Automatic Fire Sprinkler Systems, is hereby amended by the deletion of the entire section. 
(d)  Section R403.1.7.3 is amended to read as follows: 
" R403.1.7.3 Footings, foundation and floor elevations. The finished grade of the surface adjacent to every building or structure shall be sloped away from the foundation for drainage. Each new building that is primarily intended for permanent residential occupancy (single and multifamily dwellings, including apartments) must be constructed so that the lowest floor elevation of the building is at or above the elevation which is the lesser of: 
(1)  One foot above the highest point of finish grade adjoining the building; or 
(2)  One foot above the curb level of the adjacent street, or one foot above the centerline of the adjacent street if no curb is present. 
(3)  Finish grade elevation is determined by measurement at points located five feet from the building's exterior walls." 
(e)  Section G2417.4.1 (406.4.1) is amended to read as follows: 
" G2417.4.1 (406.4.1) Test pressure. Test shall be measured by an approved diaphragm gauge with a 3 1/2-inch face, 0-15 PSI gas assembly with set hands. This diaphragm gauge shall be pumped to 10 PSI." 
(f)  Section P2501 is amended by the addition of the following new paragraph: 
P2501.3. All plumbing work must be done under the supervision of a master plumber licensed by the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Secs. 14-38-14-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COMMERCIAL BUILDING CODE

(a)  International Building Code. The International Building Code, 2009 Edition, as published by the International Code Council, a copy of which is attached hereto and made a part hereof for all purposes, an authentic copy of which has been filed with the city secretary, is hereby adopted and made a part of this Code of Ordinances. The adoption of the International Building Code includes the adoption of all appendices to such code except Appendix B, Appendix C, and Appendix D which are expressly not adopted.

The building official may also recommend other local amendments to the International Building Code. Local amendments to the International Building Code shall be adopted by ordinance and shall control over any conflicting provisions of the International Building Code.

Sec. 14-42. - Amendments to the International Building Code. 
    The International Building Code adopted in section 14-41 is amended as follows: 
(a)  Section 703.6 is amended to read as follows: 
Section 703.6 Marking and identification. All fire resistive walls that have a fire resistive rating or any other wall required to have protected openings or penetrations must be effectively and permanently identified with signs or stenciling. Such identification shall: 
1)  Be located on both sides of the wall where visible without the removal of permanent building materials. 
2)  Be repeated at intervals not exceeding 10 feet measured horizontally along the wall or partition; and 
3)  Include lettering not less than 1 inch in height, incorporating the suggested wording: "FIRE AND/OR SMOKE BARRIER - PROTECT ALL OPENINGS," or other wording. 
4)  The wording shall include the U.L. listing for the wall or the prescriptive method if obtained from the 2009 International Building Code. 
5)  This section applies to all projects requiring a building permit. 
(b)  Section 903.2.7(4) is amended to read as follows: 
4.  A Group M occupancy used for the display and sale of upholstered furniture or mattresses that exceeds 5,000 square feet (464 m 2 ). 
(c)  Section 912.2 is amended by the addition of the following paragraph: 
912.2.3 Installation of fire department connections. Fire department connections shall not be located on the building they serve. Fire department connections shall be located away from the building at least a distance of one and a half times the building height. 
(d)  Section 912.5 is amended by the addition of the following paragraph: 
912.5.1 The installation of the backflow device shall be located at the fire department connection within a vault. The vault shall be approved by the public works director. 
(e)  Section 1612.3 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
1612.3 Flood Hazard Areas. The Flood Insurance Study for the City of Oak Ridge North, as amended or revised, with accompanying Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) and Flood Boundary and Floodway Map (FBFM), including related supporting data and revisions thereto, is hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this section. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12; Ord. No. 16-2013, § 1, 3-25-13)
