ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICAL CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-48. - Object and scope of article; penalty for violations. 
(a)  The object of this article is to reduce the personal hazard and the fire hazard from electrical causes. To accomplish this, the requirements set forth in this article are intended to provide a minimum standard for electrical installation in the city. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate a provision of this article or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements of this article shall upon conviction be punished by a fine not to exceed $2,000.00. Each day a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-49. - Application of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to installation in railway cars, automotive equipment, electrical railway companies, to installations used by electrical public utility telephone and telegraph companies, radio transmission stations, in the generation, transmission, or in the distribution of electricity or for the operation of signals or the transmission of intelligence, in the exercise of their function as such agencies and located outdoors or in buildings used exclusively for that purpose; provided, however, that these regulations, except as to permits, shall apply to all such wiring and equipment installed in or on the consumer's premises. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-50. - Approval required to connect and/or reconnect electrical service. 
    It shall be unlawful for any public service company operating in the city, to furnish current to any new building, tent, structure or outdoor wiring of any kind, nature or description, without first obtaining approval from the building official stating that such wiring is approved and a permit has been issued for the use of current. Whenever any service is discontinued to any building structure for any cause whatever, excepting nonpayment of bill, a clearance will be necessary before each building or structure can be reconnected. Any time a building is vacated the building official must make certain that there has not been any unauthorized additions made to wiring of such building that might create a fire hazard, or that the wiring has not become in such a condition as to be hazardous. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-51. - Municipal registration of state licensed electricians. 
(a)  A person may not perform electrical work within the city unless the person holds an appropriate state electrical occupation license issued or recognized under the authority of the Texas Electrical Safety and Licensing Act (V.T.C.A., Occupations Code ch. 1305) and is registered with the building official to perform electrical work in the city. 
(b)  A person may register to perform electrical work in the city by completing the form prescribed by the building official. The registration form must be accompanied by: 
(1)  The required registration fee; 
(2)  A copy of the registrant's state electrical occupation license; 
(3)  A copy of the registrant's driver's license or some other form of photo identification; and 
(4)  Proof of insurance as required by law. 
(c)  Persons holding state electrical occupation licenses of the following classes must register on or before September 1st of every year. The registration fee as set out in the schedule of fees must accompany the initial and each renewal registration by a: 
(1)  Electrical contractor. 
(2)  Electrical sign contractor. 
(3)  Residential appliance installation contractor. 
(4)  Master electrician. 
(5)  Master sign electrician. 
(6)  Journeyman electrician. 
(7)  Journeyman sign electrician. 
(8)  Residential wireman. 
(9)  Maintenance electrician. 
(10)  Apprentice electrician. 
(11)  Residential appliance installer. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-52. - Electrical inspector duties generally. 
    It shall be the duty of the building official or electrical inspector to enforce the provisions of this article. The building official or electrical inspector shall, upon application, grant permits for the installation or alterations of electrical equipment, and shall make inspections of electrical installations as provided in this article. The building official or electrical inspector shall keep complete records of all permits issued, inspection, and re-inspections made, and other official work performed in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-53. - Authority generally. 
(a)  The building official or electrical inspector shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building or premises in the discharge of his official duties, or for the purpose of making any inspections, re-inspections, or test of the electrical equipment contained therein or its installation. When any electrical equipment is found by the building official or electrical inspector to be dangerous to persons or to property because it is defective or defectively installed, the person responsible for the electrical equipment shall be notified in writing and shall make any changes or repairs required in the judgment of the city electrician and/or building official to place such equipment in safe condition, and if such work is not completed within 15 days or any longer period that may be specified by the city electrician and/or building official in such notice, the building official or electrical inspector shall have authority to disconnect or order discontinuance of electrical service to such electrical equipment. In cases of emergency, where necessary for safety of persons or of property or where electrical equipment may interfere with the work of the fire department, the building official or electrical inspector shall have the authority to immediately disconnect or cause to be disconnected any electrical equipment. 
(b)  The building official or electrical inspector shall have the right to remove or compel the removal of any obstruction such as lath, plastering, ceiling or flooring which may hinder a full and complete inspection of such wires or apparatus. 
(c)  The building official or electrical inspector may remove or compel the removal of any conductors which are enclosed in conduit or otherwise inaccessible for complete inspection. When such conductors or appliances are not in accordance with the requirements of this article or found to be unsafe to life and property, the building official or electrical inspector shall have the right to condemn such conductors or appliances as provided in this division. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder or interfere with the building official or electrical inspector or any of their deputies in the discharge of their duties under this article. 
(e)  The building official or electrical inspector may delegate any of their powers or duties to any of their assistants. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-54. - Authority to disconnect service due to hazardous conditions. 
    Whenever any electrical conductor or electrical material in or on any building or any electrical conductor on any pole line or any conductor underground becomes, or is in a condition that is dangerous to life or property, the building official or electrical inspector is hereby empowered to condemn, disconnect and cause the owner of such conductor or material to immediately correct the condition or have it removed. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-55. - Conflict of interests. 
    It shall be unlawful for the building official or electrical inspector or for any of their assistants to engage in the business of the sale, installation, or maintenance of electrical equipment, either directly or indirectly and they shall have no financial interest in any concern engaged in such business in the city at any time while holding such office as provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Secs. 14-56-14-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STANDARDS 

Sec. 14-61. - Conformance with article, state law and national codes. 
(a)  All installations of electrical equipment shall be in strict conformity with provisions of this article, the statutes of the state, the rules and regulations issued under authority of the state statutes, and shall be in conformity with approved standards of construction for safety to life and property. In every case where no specific type or class of material, or no specific standard of construction are prescribed by the statutes of the state, the regulations issued under the authority of the state statutes or by this article, conformity with the regulations in the National Electrical Code, adopted in section 14-62, and other installation and safety regulations shall be prima facie evidence of conformity with approved standards of construction for safety to life and property. 
(b)  Unless by this article, by a statute of the state or by any orders, rules or regulations issued by authority thereof, a specific type or class of electrical equipment is disapproved for installation and use, conformity with the standards of Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., or other nationally recognized approval agency, as approved by the NFPA, and the electrical provisions of other standards approved by the NFPA shall be prima facie evidence of conformity with approved standards for safety to persons and property, provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to equipment owned and used by an electrical supply or communication agency in the generation, transmission, or distribution of electricity or for the operation of signals or the transmission of intelligence. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-62. - National Electrical Code adopted. 
(a)  The National Electric Code published by the National Fire Protection Association, as adopted by the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation pursuant to the provisions of the Texas Electrical Safety and Licensing Act (V.T.C.A., Occupations Code ch. 1305) is hereby adopted as the electrical construction code of the city. 
(b)  The city may amend the provisions of the National Electric Code by ordinance. In the event of any conflict between the National Electric Code and the provisions of this chapter or any other amending ordinance, the provisions of the amendment shall control over any contrary provisions of the National Electric Code. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-63. - Installation to be done by a master electrician. 
    Every master electrician or their qualified representative shall direct and superintend all electrical work installed by him in the city. There shall be a journeyman electrician on the job at all times. The master electrician or their qualified representative will be allowed to take out permits. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-64. - Installation to be done in workmanlike manner. 
    All work shall be executed in a neat and workmanlike manner. Slipshod work, or work not in keeping with good electrical practice shall be classed as defective and shall be immediately corrected by persons causing such defective work. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-65. - Approved wiring methods and materials. 
    The following wiring methods and materials are hereby approved: 
(1)  No conductor smaller than #12 AWG shall be permitted within the city limits with the exception of control wiring. 
(2)  All conductors shall be copper. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-66. - Electric metering required. 
(a)  No permit, certificate or other authorization issued by the city under the provisions of this code, for the construction or occupancy of a new apartment house or conversion to a condominium shall be issued unless the construction plan submitted by the applicant as part of the process for the approval of such permit, certificate, or other authorization for the construction or occupancy of a new apartment house or conversion to a condominium provides for individual metering by the utility company or sub-metering by the owner of each dwelling unit for the measurement of the quantity of electricity, if any, consumed by the occupants within that dwelling unit. For the purposes of this section, the terms "individual electric metering" and "sub-metering" shall be defined pursuant to the provisions of V.T.C.A., Utilities Code § 184.011 et seq. 
(b)  The provisions hereof adopted by subsection (a) of this section shall not prohibit the issuance of any certificate of occupancy as issued under the provisions of the electrical code of the city for a new apartment house or conversion to a condominium when a building permit was issued pursuant to the provisions of the electrical code of the city for the construction of such new apartment house or conversion to a condominium, prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Secs. 14-67-14-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 14-76. - Permit required. 
    Before proceeding with the installation, alteration of, or the addition to any electrical wiring or equipment within or on any building, structure or premises, publicly or privately owned in the city, the master electrician or master sign electrician in charge of such proposed work shall first file with the building official an application requesting the inspection and shall secure a permit therefore. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-77. - Application. 
(a)  Application for inspection and permit, required by this article, describing the work to be done, shall be made in writing to the building official by the master electrician or master sign electrician installing the work, shall give the exact street number of the premises on which work is to be done, date inspection is desired, name of the owner or occupant, name of the electrician doing work and class of wiring. 
(b)  On all applications where plans and specifications require installation above the minimum standards as set forth in this article, the plans and specifications for such work shall be accompanied with application for inspection. No deviation may be made from installation described in such plans and specifications without the written approval of the owner or architect. 
(c)  On all applications where plans do not show minimum standards as set forth in this article, master electricians or contractors shall obtain the written permission of the building official before proceeding with installation. 
(d)  All applications for inspections shall be accompanied by the inspection fees as provided for in section 14-79. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-78. - When a permit is not required. 
    No permit will be required to execute any of the following work: 
(1)  The replacement of lamps, or the connection of portable electrical equipment to suitable permanently installed receptacles. 
(2)  The installation, alteration, or repair of electrical equipment for the operation of signals or for the transmission of intelligence by wire by a communication agency. 
(3)  The installation, alteration or repair of electrical equipment installed by or for an electrical supply agency for the use of such agency in the generation transmission and distribution of electricity. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-79. - Fees. 
    The fees for permits and inspections under this article shall be as set forth in schedule of fees. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-80. - Inspections generally. 
(a)  Master electricians shall at all times, keep the building official notified of the progress of their work and shall request inspections as the work progresses. Upon receipt of an application requesting inspection, the building official shall inspect or cause to be inspected such work within 72 hours after receiving applications, weekends and holidays not included in this time. After inspecting the electrical wiring covered by an application obtained by the master electrician, the building official shall leave a tag, which shall state that the work had been inspected and approved or that it is not approved and must be held open for correction. The master electrician is to be notified if the wiring is to be held open for correction and no person, including the general contractor or his representative shall lath, coil or in any manner conceal any wiring until they are informed that such wiring has been approved by the building official. 
(b)  The master electrician shall have all electrical work installed by them inspected before such work is covered or concealed. All cabinet and panelboard covers or trims shall be left off for final inspection, and any fitting or cover that conceals any wiring which may hinder the proper inspection of electrical work shall be removed by master electrician at the request of the building official. 
(c)  The master electricians making extensions or additions to existing electrical systems shall before proceeding with such work ascertain from the building official whether any of the old work must be changed or must be brought up to the requirements of this article. 
(d)  Upon completion and receipt of final inspection papers covering electrical work, the building official shall make a final inspection, and if such work is found to comply with this article, a certificate of inspection shall be issued stating that the work has been done according to the provisions of this article and the rules governing the respective class to which it belongs. 
(e)  This certificate shall not relieve the master electrician of his responsibility for any defective work that may have been concealed or escaped the notice of the inspector. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Secs. 14-81-14-90. - Reserved.

Sec. 14-93. - Responsibility for defects unchanged. 
    The provisions of this article or the enforcement or failure to enforce the provisions of this article shall not relieve or lessen the responsibility or liability of any person owning, operating, controlling or installing any plumbing, gas piping or gas fired appliances, for damages to persons or property caused by any defect therein. The city shall not be regarded as assuming any liability by reason of the inspections authorized in this article or by virtue of any certificates of approval issued under this article. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Secs. 14-94-14-96. - Reserved.

(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12)

ARTICLE VI. - MECHANICAL CODE 

Sec. 14-101. - International Mechanical Code adopted. 
(a)  International Mechanical Code. The International Mechanical Code, 2009 Edition, as published by the International Code Council, a copy of which is attached hereto and made a part hereof for all purposes, an authentic copy of which has been filed with the city secretary, is hereby adopted and made a part of this Code. The adoption of the International Residential Code includes the adoption of all appendices to such code except Appendix B which is expressly not adopted. 
(b)  The building official shall periodically review amendments to the 2009 International Mechanical Code as published by the International Code Council, and may recommend the adoption of such amendments to the city council. The building official may also recommend other local amendments to the International Mechanical Code. Local amendments to the International Mechanical Code shall be adopted by ordinance and shall control over any conflicting provisions of the International Mechanical Code. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-102. - Amendments to the International Mechanical Code. 
    The International Mechanical Code adopted in section 14-101 is amended as follows: 
(a)  Section 106.5.2 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
106.5.2 Fee Schedule. The fees for permits required hereunder shall be in accordance with the schedule of fees as established from time to time by the City Council of the City of Oak Ridge North. 
(b)  Section 106.5.3 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
106.5.3. Fee Refunds. Refunds for fees otherwise required hereunder shall be made only as provided from time to time by the City Council of the City of Oak Ridge North. 
(c)  Section 109.2 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
109.2 Membership of the Board. The board of appeals shall be appointed by the City Council of the City of Oak Ridge North. The qualifications of members of the board, and the terms for which such members shall serve, shall be as determined by the City Council. The City Council may remove any member of the board at any time, with or without cause, regardless of whether such member has been appointed for a definite or an indefinite term. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Secs. 14-103, 14-104. - Reserved.

    The city hereby adopts the Standard Swimming Pool Code 1999 edition, for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the construction of swimming pools, including fees, permits and penalties, save and except such portions as are deleted, modified or amended in this article and such portions as are in conflict with any provisions of the City Code. One copy of the Standard Swimming Pool Code is filed in the office of the city secretary. This swimming pool code is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as is set out at length in this section. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12)

    The Standard Swimming Pool Code adopted in section 14-111 is amended as follows: 
Section 105.6, Schedule of fees, is amended to read as follows: For each private or public swimming pool, there shall be a building permit fee as indicated in the schedule set out in the schedule of fees. All other piping, fixtures and equipment shall be subject to and in compliance with present city codes, and fees shall be charged accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Secs. 14-113-14-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - ROOFING MATERIALS 

Sec. 14-116. - Scope. 
    This article shall be known, and may be recited as the city's "roofing ordinance." The provisions of this article shall apply to all roofing projects and materials within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 60-2014, § 2, 11-10-14) 
Sec. 14-117. - Definitions. 
    Accessory building See Appendix A, section 3 of the Code of Ordinances, as may be amended. 
    Detached accessory building means a building that is detached from the main building, the use of which is incidental and subordinate to that of the main building. 
    Deterioration means to weaken, disintegrate, corrode, rust or decay and lose effectiveness for an intended purpose. 
    Neglect means the lack of proper maintenance for a roof and its necessary components. 
(Ord. No. 60-2014, § 2, 11-10-14) 
Sec. 14-118. - Permit required. 
    A permit is required before the installation, replacement, or re-roofing of any building in the city is permitted. Permit fees may be found in the schedule of fees adopted by city council, as may be amended. 
(Ord. No. 60-2014, § 2, 11-10-14) 
Sec. 14-119. - Roofing materials-Residential. 
(a)  Existing wood shingles or shake roofs cannot be overlaid, and must be removed prior to re-roofing. 
(b)  All roofing materials shall meet the following criteria. 
(1)  All roofing material must be an approved color. An approved color chart is located at city hall for review. 
(2)  All roofing material must carry a fire resistance rating of A or B per ASTM E108 or UL790. 
(3)  All roofing material, components, and installation shall meet all current building code requirements as adopted by the city, as may be amended. 
(4)  The roofing material shall have a 30 year or greater warranty. 
(c)  Metal roofs are permitted only if the proposed metal roofing material has the appearance of a composition shingle roof or tile roof. 
(1)  Exception . Metal roofing material that does not have the appearance of a composition shingle roof or tile roof may be used only as accent roofing above windows or porches provided the total metal roofing area does not exceed 10 percent of the first floor square footage. 
(d)  Roofing material for detached accessory buildings that exceed 144 square feet in area shall have the same roofing material as the main residence. 
(e)  Roofing materials that do not meet the criteria set forth in subsections 14-119.B. or 14-119.C. above must be submitted to the city council for approval prior to their use and installation. 
(Ord. No. 60-2014, § 2, 11-10-14) 
Sec. 14-120. - Reserved. 
Sec. 14-121. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined a sum of not more than $500.00. 
(b)  Each and every day or fraction of a day that any person violates any provision of this article or any part thereof shall be deemed a separate offense and punishable as such. 
(Ord. No. 60-2014, § 2, 11-10-14) 
Sec. 14-122. - Nonconforming roofing. 
    It is the declared purpose of this section that roofing not conforming to this article be eliminated and replaced with roofing that complies with this article, having due regard for the property rights of the persons affected, the public welfare, and the character of the surrounding areas. Any nonconforming roofing material which lawfully existed at the time of the passage of this article may be continued until such time the existing roofing material is substantially deteriorated or such time that the existing roofing material has been substantially neglected as determined by the building official, or his/her designee. For the purpose of this article, the terms "substantially deteriorated" and "substantially neglected" shall mean the deterioration or the neglect, respectively, of roofing material in an amount that is greater than or equal to 51 percent of the total roofing material covering the main residential or commercial building. Upon the building official making a substantially deteriorated or substantially neglected determination, all roofing material covering all buildings must be replaced such that it is consistent and complies with this article. 
(Ord. No. 60-2014, § 2, 11-10-14) 
Sec. 14-123. - Appeal. 
    Any person affected by a "substantially deteriorated" or "substantially neglected" determination may appeal the determination of the building official or his/her designee to the city manager. The city manager must receive the notice of appeal within five business days from the date the person receives written notice of a "substantially deteriorated" or "substantially neglected" determination. A hearing on the appeal before the city council shall take place within 15 business days from the date the city manager timely receives the notice of appeal. The decision of the city council or their designee shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 60-2014, § 2, 11-10-14) 
Secs. 14-124-18-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - REGISTRATION AND INSPECTION OF RESIDENTIAL RENTAL UNITS 

Sec. 14-136. - Definitions. 
    Owner means any person holding title according to the deed records in the county clerk's office of the county in which the property is situated, or the duly authorized agent of the person holding title. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, or any other legal entity; or their legal representatives, agents, or assigns. 
    Rental unit means one or more habitable rooms, including all or part of an efficiency unit, single family rental unit, a duplex rental unit, a townhome rental unit, a condominium rental unit, a manufactured home rental unit, or an individual multifamily rental unit which is intended to be occupied by one or more persons for living, sleeping, cooking, eating and sanitation purposes, and which is rented or offered for rent. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-137. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to safeguard the life, health, safety, welfare, and property of individuals who, by rent, lease, or permission, occupy a rental unit and the general public by developing a process to enforce the minimum building standards, and to provide equitable and practical criminal, administrative, and civil penalties for the violation of minimum building standards. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-138. - Registration required. 
(a)  An owner who rents, leases to, or allows another person to occupy a rental unit is required to register by this article, shall file with the city a written registration application, on the form provided for that purpose, and signed by the owner of the rental to be registered. 
(b)  The registration shall be on a form prescribed by the building official, and shall at a minimum contain the following information: 
(1)  The trade name, physical address, and business address; 
(2)  The names, addresses, and telephone numbers of the owner, property manager, and resident manager; and the type of business entity that owns the property; 
(3)  The name and physical address of designated employees or authorized representatives who shall be assigned to respond to emergency conditions at the rental unit, and a telephone number where said employees can be contacted during any 24-hour period. Emergency conditions shall include fire, natural disaster, flood, burst pipes, collapse hazard, and violent crime. A post office box shall not suffice for the address requirements of this section; 
(4)  The names, addresses, and telephone numbers of any mortgagees of the rental unit; 
(5)  If the property is owned by a corporation, limited liability company, partnership, limited partnership, trust or real estate investment trust, the name and address of any of the following: 
a.  For a corporation, a corporate officer; 
b.  For a partnership, a general partner; 
c.  For a limited liability company, the managing or administrative member; 
d.  For a limited partnership, a general partner; 
e.  For a limited liability partnership, a general partner; 
f.  For a limited liability limited partnership, a general partner; 
g.  For a trust, a trustee; 
h.  For a real estate investment trust, a general partner or an officer; 
i.  For any other legal entity not named above, a duly authorized agent. 
(6)  If the property is owned by a person, other than an individual, who lives outside the state, the owner shall designate a registered agent in the state, who will accept legal service on behalf of the owner. If the property is owned by a person who is an individual and who lives outside the state, the individual shall either designate a registered agent, in the state who will accept legal service on behalf of the owner or provide a physical address where the owner may receive legal service. A designation of a registered agent under this section shall include the name and address of the agent; and 
(7)  If any change in the information required by this section occurs the owner shall notify the building official within 30 days of the change in a manner prescribed by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-139. - Fees. 
(a)  A permit and inspection fee for the first rental unit and for each additional rental unit, if any, required to register shall be established by council by resolution and shall be: 
(1)  Submitted with the registration form required by this article; and 
(2)  Submitted with a new registration upon a change of ownership of any rental unit. 
(b)  A registration is valid for one year from the date the completed registration form is filed in the office of the building official, and payment of the registration fee for that year has been made, unless the ownership of the property changes. 
(c)  A registration is not assignable or transferable. If a change of ownership of the property occurs during the period that a registration is otherwise valid, the landlord of the property shall have 30 days from the date the change of ownership occurred to file a new registration with the building official, and pay a new registration fee. 
(d)  If a rental unit fails a follow-up inspection, the city shall assess the owner a reinspection fee as established by resolution of city council. Written notice of the reinspection fee shall be sent by the building official via U.S. mail to the owner. 
(e)  The owner of a rental unit must file with the building official a written request for an administrative hearing not later than the 30th day after the fee is assessed under subsection (d). The fee shall be considered assessed on the date the notice is mailed by the city to the owner. 
(f)  An administrative hearing shall be conducted by the building official on the assessment of a fee under subsection (d) not later than the 20th day after the date the hearing request is filed. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-140. - Inspection and reporting. 
(a)  An owner shall inspect each rental unit for compliance with the following standards: 
(1)  Street address of the rental until, or in the case of multifamily dwelling complexes, of the complex; 
(2)  Owner's name; 
(3)  The number of adults occupying the unit, and the number of bedrooms contained therein; 
(4)  If owner is a person, mailing address, physical address, work telephone number, home telephone number; 
(5)  If owner is a partnership, the name of all partners, the principal business address, the tax ID number, and telephone number of each partner; 
(6)  If owner is a corporation, the state of incorporation, the name and address of the registered agent, the names of all officers, and the contact information of any local office of such corporation; 
(7)  Name and address of the property manager, if any; and 
(8)  Signature of owner or owner's agent. 
(b)  Upon registration of said rental property, an inspection shall be performed by the building official to determine if the premise will not threaten the health and safety of the occupants, and must meet city safety standards prior to occupancy. 
(c)  The inspection of a rental unit shall be conducted a minimum of once annually and at any time when the occupancy changes. Inspections shall be recorded on a form approved by the building official. 
(d)  The owner shall sign each inspection report, and shall require a tenant to sign the report for the tenant's rental unit. If the tenant disagrees with any notation made by the owner on the report, the owner shall permit the tenant to make written comments on the report prior to signing it. The owner shall provide the tenant with a copy of the report after it is signed. 
(e)  An owner shall maintain a copy of the report of every inspection conducted pursuant to this section for a minimum of three years. A copy of the reports maintained by an owner pursuant to this subsection shall be provided to the building official upon request. 
(f)  A notice for reporting Code violations to the city shall be provided to the tenants once annually and at any time when the occupancy changes. The notice shall be in a form provided by the building official. 
(g)  The building official may conduct: 
(1)  Inspections based on indication of Code violations; 
(2)  Periodic inspections; and 
(3)  Follow-up or reinspections. 
(h)  The following areas shall be subject to periodic inspection by the building official: 
(1)  All building exteriors pursuant to International Property Maintenance Code; 
(2)  All building interiors; 
(3)  Vacant rental units, with the owner's consent; and 
(4)  Occupied rental units upon receipt of complaint by the unit's tenant during a periodic inspection. 
(i)  The building official is authorized to make follow-up inspections of a rental unit that fails an initial inspection or a periodic inspection. 
(j)  In addition to other authority granted by this article, the building official has all rights and authority granted by V.T.C.A., Code of Criminal Procedure art. 18.05. Inspections shall comply with all federal, state, and local laws, regulations, and ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-141. - Criminal enforcement. 
    A violation of this article is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed $2,000.00. Each separate occurrence of a violation or each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-142. - Civil enforcement. 
(a)  The city may invoke V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 54.012-54.019, as amended, and petition the state district court or the applicable county court at law, through the city attorney, for either injunctive relief, civil penalties, or both injunctive relief and civil penalties, whenever it appears that a person has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this chapter. 
(b)  Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.016, as amended, the city may obtain against the owner or the operator of a facility, a temporary or permanent injunction, as appropriate, that: 
(1)  Prohibits specific conduct that violates the ordinance; or 
(2)  Requires specific conduct that is necessary for compliance with the ordinance. 
(c)  Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.017, as amended, the city may recover a civil penalty of not more than $1,000.00 per day for each violation of any provision of this chapter that relates to any matter specified in subsection (a), if the city proves that: 
(1)  The defendant was actually notified of the provisions of the chapter; and 
(2)  After the defendant received notice of the ordinance provisions, the defendant committed acts in violation of the ordinances or failed to take action necessary for compliance with the ordinance. 
(d)  The city may also institute suit to recover the cost of any actual damages incurred by the city, and any costs of response, remediation, abatement, and restoration incurred by the city as allowed under state or federal laws, or at common law. 
(e)  In determining the amount of civil liability, the court should take into account all relevant circumstances, including, but not limited to, the extent of harm caused by the violation, the magnitude and duration of the violation, any economic benefit gained through the violation, corrective actions by the violator, the compliance history of the violator, and any other factors as justice requires. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Secs. 14-143-14-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - STORM DRAINAGE 
DIVISION 1. - DITCHES, SEWERS AND CULVERTS 

Sec. 14-151. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Owner includes contractors, subcontractors, agents and their employees and representatives; provided, however, that all penalties and charges shall be made against the land or the owner of the property. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-152. - Penalty for violation of article. 
(a)  If any owner shall violate any of the provisions of this article, he shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-4 for each day during which such violation is permitted to exist. 
(b)  This penalty shall be in addition to any other penalties provided by the laws of the state and may be enforced by complaint filed in the municipal court of the city. Each day any such violation shall be permitted to exist shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-153. - Conflicting provisions. 
    If the terms of this article shall conflict with the terms of any other ordinance valid and on the books of the city, then, insofar as the subject matter of this article is concerned, the terms of this article shall prevail over the terms of any other ordinance giving rise to such conflict. At all times, the terms of this article shall yield to the laws, rules and regulations of the state and its governmental agencies. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-154. - Inspections generally. 
(a)  The city shall appoint inspectors whose duty it shall be to inspect all work and materials and to prevent any deviation from specifications and requirements as set out in this article. The owner will not thereby be relieved from his obligations to supervise the work and fulfill, to the letter, all terms of such requirements. 
(b)  The owner shall give at least 24 hours' notice when requesting any inspection. 
(c)  If an inspector should be negligent or absent or should consent to the allowance of inferior work, the owner will not thereby be excused or relieved from repairing or removing faulty work or material at his own expense. 
(d)  At such time as a final inspection is made pursuant to the terms of this article for ditches or culverts, such inspection and final approval shall be evidenced in writing by the inspector, with one copy of such approval being given to the property owner and the other being placed on file in the city office. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-155. - Failure to request inspection. 
    If at any time, any agent or employee of the city shall be made aware, by whatever circumstances, of a violation of this article insofar as inspections are concerned, then the city shall notify the owner of its intention to make an inspection of ditches and culverts as may be covered by this article and shall give notice of such inspection to the owner in writing not less than three days prior to the date of such inspection. The owner shall incur normal expenses in connection with any such inspection on behalf of the city. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-156. - Notice of violation; remedial action by city on failure to comply with notice. 
(a)  If, at any time, the city shall be cognizant of any violation of the terms of this article, including but not limited to violations during the period of time of construction, then the city shall give the owner written notice of such violation, which notice shall demand that immediate steps be taken by the owner to bring himself in compliance with this article. 
(b)  If the owner fails to comply with this article pursuant to the notice given, then the city may pursue any one of its remedies as provided in this article, including but not limited to prosecution as provided in this article. 
(c)  At the option of the city, if the owner fails to comply with the request for correction of violation as per written notice given, then the city may notify the owner that, unless compliance is made within the number of days specified in such notice, which time limit shall always be reasonable, and if the owner still fails to comply within the specified number of days, then the city, through its own employees or through independent contractors, may take such steps as are necessary to correct the violations of this article. If expenses are incurred on behalf of the city to correct violations of this article as specified in this section, then any charges shall be charged to the owner and he shall be given written notice of such charges. If such charges are not paid within ten days from date of receipt of notice of such charges, then the city may proceed to file a lien on the property for such charges as prescribed by the laws of the state. If it becomes necessary for the city to pursue collection of such monies through probate, bankruptcy or use of an attorney, then the owner shall also be responsible for any court cost and reasonable attorney's fees as may be incurred in such collection. It is specifically provided, however, that there shall be no obligation on the part of the city to correct violations pursuant to the terms of this section and at the discretion of the city the terms and specifications of this article may be enforced by prosecution as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-157. - Emergency measures. 
(a)  If any violation under the terms of this article shall be deemed to constitute an emergency threatening the property of either the city, other persons or the owner, or shall constitute an obstruction or danger to the water flow of the city, then the city may correct the violation without notice to the owner. 
(b)  Within 24 hours after correction of any emergency situation, the city shall notify the owner of any expenses or charges as may have been incurred in connection with correction of the emergency, and the owner shall have ten days within which to make payment thereon. If the owner fails to pay within ten days as specified, the city may proceed to collect such monies due as is provided in section 14-156. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-158. - Correction of hazardous conditions created by existing improvements. 
(a)  If an owner of existing improvements shall fail to comply with sections 14-159 and 14-160 and is deemed to create a hazardous condition to the city, its residents, their property or health, the city shall give written notice of such failure and the owner shall have 40 days following the date of notice within which to complete construction and sodding as required in this article. 
(b)  If an owner of existing improvements is notified of a hazardous condition, he may file an appeal within ten days to the city secretary. This appeal will be heard at the next regularly scheduled city council meeting. This appeal shall stay the 40-day time limit provided in subsection (a) of this section. Should the appeal be denied the 40-day time limit will begin on the day following the council meeting. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-159. - Location and grade of ditches and culverts; grade stakes. 
(a)  Within ten days following issuance of any building permit for new construction, the property owner shall request in writing that the engineer or designated official for the city provide construction stakes, which stakes shall indicate proper elevation and grades for all ditches immediately adjoining the subject property. 
(b)  Any irregularity in construction stakes discovered by the owner shall be reported to the engineer or designated official for correction before proceeding with any work on such ditches or culverts. 
(c)  The stakes shall be left in place until construction has been completed and inspection of ditches made as provided in this article. The owner shall exercise reasonable care for the preservation of stakes set, and if such stakes are damaged, lost or removed by owner then the cost of resetting such stakes may be charged to the owner. 
(d)  If there are discrepancies in location, grade or slope of any ditch or culvert, the owner shall be responsible for making necessary corrections unless grade stakes are left in place and show evidence of an error in staking. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-160. - Sodding of ditches. 
(a)  All property owners, including builders of homes under construction or completed which have not been occupied, shall sod or seed with grass ditches immediately adjoining the owner's property in front and on the sides, where applicable, of such property. Such sodding or seeding shall begin at the top of the slope of such ditches and shall completely cover both sides and the bottom of such ditches. 
(b)  When cutting ditches to grade, all ditches shall be cut to such a depth so as to provide that the depth of such ditch after planting the grass will be at the proper elevation. 
(c)  The surface shall be left in a smooth condition and shall be left clean and clear of any large rocks, stumps, trash or other debris. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-161. - Construction of culverts. 
(a)  Before starting construction or placement of any culvert, the owner shall comply with the provisions of section 14-59, and thereafter shall comply with all other provisions of this article. 
(b)  The bottom of the trench to receive any culvert shall be cut to such a depth so that, after the culvert is in place, the inside of the bottom of such culvert shall be laid to the grade of the ditch after sodding as set out in this article and as designated by the engineer for the city. If the bottom of the trench is such that proper bearing thereon cannot be obtained as required in this article, then the owner shall furnish and replace suitable materials in the trench so that the culvert may be laid as specified. 
(c)  If the owner is required to excavate for laying of culvert, the topsoil shall be excavated and placed separately from subsoil and thereafter replaced so as to return the ditch to its original condition as nearly as is practical. The surface shall be left in a smooth condition and shall be left clean and clear of any large rocks, stumps, trash or other debris. 
(d)  No culvert pipe of less than the inside diameter of the nearest upstream culvert shall be installed, and larger diameters may be required by the city or its designated agent. The minimum diameter of a culvert pipe allowed at an upstream location will be 18 inches. 
(e)  All refuse, broken pipe, excess fill material, vegetation, large rocks, stumps and other debris shall be removed by the owner as soon after construction is completed as is reasonably possible, and in any event shall be removed prior to inspection by the city as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
State Law reference- Trench excavation safety, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 756.021 et seq. 
Sec. 14-162. - Cleaning and repair of drainage devices by city. 
    The city is empowered to clean or repair any and all drainage devices within the boundaries of the city. The city shall at its discretion perform this service as deemed required, and may elect to fund this operation through general revenue or special assessment as required. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-163. - Obstructing drainage system; unauthorized drainage structures. 
(a)  Except as specifically provided in this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be placed or deposited any debris, fill, sand, stone or other materials of any kind or nature or construction of any kind into or across any ditch, culvert, pipe, watercourse or other drainage system except in strict compliance with the terms of this article and pursuant to the specifications of the engineer for the city. 
(b)  Except as specifically provided in this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to construct or place any ditch, pipe, culvert or artificial watercourse of any kind or nature which shall collect and direct the flow of natural surface waters or drainage or increase in intensity or quantity the flow of surface waters or drainage from paved surfaces, structures, roads or improvements, directly into any stream, ditch, culvert, pipe or watercourse or other drainage system within the city, except in strict compliance with the terms of this article and pursuant to the specifications of the engineer for the city. 
(c)  Except as specifically provided in this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to fill, obstruct, dam or divert or otherwise change or alter the natural or artificial flow of waters or drainage or the intensity or quantity of flow through any ditch, pipe, culvert, watercourse or other improvement or drainage system of the city, or to permit any vegetation to grow in any such watercourse so as to constitute a constriction, unless such is in strict compliance with the terms of this article and the specifications as provided by the engineer for the city. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Secs. 14-164-14-189. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DRAINAGE 

Sec. 14-190. - Definitions. 
    Best management practices (BMPs) shall mean schedules of activities, prohibitions of practices, general good housekeeping practices, pollution prevention and educational practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices to prevent or reduce the discharge of pollutants directly or indirectly to storm water, receiving waters, or storm water conveyance systems. BMPs also include treatment practices, operating procedures, and practices to control site runoff, spillage or leaks, sludge or water disposal, or drainage from raw materials storage. 
    Clean Water Act (CWA) shall mean the Federal Water Pollution Control Act or Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972 (33 U.S.C. § 1251 et seq.) and any subsequent amendments thereto. 
    Construction activity shall mean activities subject to TPDES construction permits. These include construction projects resulting in land disturbance of one acre or more. Such activities include but are not limited to clearing and grubbing, grading, excavating, and demolition. 
    Hazardous materials shall mean any material, including any substance, waste, or combination thereof, which because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics may cause, or significantly contribute to, a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, safety, property, or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
    Illegal discharge shall mean any direct or indirect non-storm water discharge to the storm water system, except as exempted in section 14-195. 
    Illicit connection shall mean any drain or conveyance connecting an illicit discharge directly to the storm water system, whether on the surface or subsurface, which allows an illegal discharge to enter the storm water system including, but not limited to, any conveyances that allow any non-storm water discharge including sewage, process wastewater, and wash water to enter the storm drain system and any connections to the storm drain system from indoor drains and sinks, regardless of whether said drain or connection had been previously allowed, permitted, or approved by the building official or, any drain or conveyance connected from a commercial or industrial land use to the storm drain system which has not been documented in plans, maps, or equivalent records and approved by the building official. 
    Industrial activity shall mean activities subject to NPDES or TPDES industrial permits as defined in 40 CFR, Section 122.26(b)(14). 
    Municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) shall mean a separate storm sewer system owned or operated by a state, city, town, county, district, association, or other public body (created by or pursuant to state law) having jurisdiction over the disposal of sewage, industrial wastes, storm water or other wastes, including special districts under state law such as a sewer district, flood control or drainage district, or similar entity. 
    National pollutant discharge elimination system (NPDES) storm water discharge permit shall mean a permit issued by EPA (or by a state under authority delegated pursuant to 33 USC § 1342(b)) that authorizes the discharge of pollutants to waters of the United States, whether the permit is applicable on an individual, group, or general area-wide basis. 
    Non-storm water discharge shall mean any discharge to the storm water drain system that is not composed entirely of storm water. 
    Person shall mean any individual, association, organization, partnership, firm, corporation, or other entity recognized by law and acting as either the owner or as the owner's agent. 
    Pollutant shall mean anything that causes or contributes to pollution. Pollutants may include, but are not limited to: paints, varnishes, and solvents; oil and other automotive fluids; non-hazardous liquid and solid wastes and yard wastes; refuse, rubbish, garbage, litter, or other discarded or abandoned objects, articles, and accumulations, so that same may cause or contribute to pollution; floatables; pesticides, herbicides, and fertilizers; hazardous substances and wastes; sewage, fecal coli form and pathogens; dissolved and particulate metals; animal wastes; wastes and residues that result from constructing a building or structure; and noxious or offensive matter of any kind. 
    Premises shall mean any building, lot, parcel of land, or portion of land whether improved or unimproved including adjacent sidewalks and parking strips. 
    Storm drainage system shall mean publicly-owned facilities by which storm water is collected and/or conveyed, including but not limited to, any roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, gutters, curbs, inlets, piped storm drains, pumping facilities, retention and detention basins, natural and human-made or altered drainage channels, reservoirs, and other drainage structures. 
    Storm water shall mean any surface flow, runoff, and drainage consisting entirely of water from any form of natural precipitation, and resulting from such precipitation. 
    Storm water pollution prevention plan (SWPPP or SWP 3 ) shall mean a document that describes the best management practices and activities to be implemented by a person or entity to identify sources of pollution or contamination at a site and the actions to eliminate or reduce pollutant discharges to storm water, storm water conveyance systems, and/or receiving waters to the maximum extent practicable. 
    Wastewater shall mean any water or other liquid, other than uncontaminated storm water, discharged from a facility. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-191. - Purpose/intent. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide for the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the city through the regulation of non-storm water discharges to the storm water system to the maximum extent practicable as required by federal and state law. This article establishes methods for controlling the introduction of pollutants into the municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) in order to comply with requirements of the Texas Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (TPDES) permit process. The objectives of this article are: 
(1)  To regulate the contribution of pollutants to the municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) by storm water discharges by any user; 
(2)  To prohibit illicit connections and discharges to the municipal separate storm sewer system; and 
(3)  To establish legal authority to carry out all inspection, surveillance and monitoring procedures necessary to ensure compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-192. - Applicability. 
    This article shall apply to all water entering the storm drain system generated on any developed and undeveloped lands unless explicitly exempted by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-193. - Responsibility for administration. 
    The building official or his/her designee shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this article. Any powers granted or duties imposed upon the building official may be delegated in writing by the building official to persons or entities acting in the beneficial interest of or in the employ of the agency. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-194. - Ultimate responsibility. 
    The standards set forth herein and promulgated pursuant to this article are minimum standards; therefore this article does not intend nor imply that compliance by any person will ensure that there will be no contamination, pollution, or unauthorized discharge of pollutants. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-195. - Discharge prohibitions. 
(a)  Prohibition of illegal discharges. It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or cause to be discharged into the municipal storm drainage system or watercourses any materials, including, but not limited to, pollutants or waters containing any pollutants that cause or contribute to a violation of applicable water quality standards, other than storm water. 
(b)  Exceptions. The commencement, conduct or continuance of any illegal discharge to the storm drainage system is prohibited except as described as follows: 
(1)  The following discharges are exempt from discharge prohibitions established by this article: 
a.  Flushing of water lines or other potable water sources; 
b.  Landscape irrigation or lawn watering; 
c.  Diverted stream flows; 
d.  Rising ground water; 
e.  Uncontaminated ground water infiltration to storm drains; 
f.  Uncontaminated pumped ground water; 
g.  Foundation or footing drains (not including active groundwater dewatering systems); 
h.  Crawl space pumps; 
i.  Air conditioning condensation; 
j.  Springs; 
k.  Non-commercial washing of vehicles; 
l.  Natural riparian habitat or wetland flows; 
m.  Swimming pools (if dechlorinated-typically less than one parts per million (PPM) chlorine); 
(2)  Discharges specified in writing by the city manager as being necessary to protect public health and safety. 
(3)  Dye testing, as long as a verbal notification is provided to the building official prior to the time of the test. 
(4)  Any non-storm water discharge permitted under an NPDES or TPDES permit, waiver, or waste discharge order issued to the discharger and administered under the authority of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) or the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ), provided that the discharger is in full compliance with all requirements of the permit, waiver, or order and other applicable laws and regulations, and provided further that written approval has been granted for any discharge to the storm drainage system. 
(c)  Prohibition of illicit connections. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful to construct, use, maintain or continue the existence of illicit connections to the city's storm drainage system. 
(2)  This prohibition expressly includes, without limitation, illicit connections made in the past, regardless of whether the connection was permissible under law or practices applicable or prevailing at the time of connection. 
(3)  A person is considered to be in violation of this article if the person connects a line conveying sewage to the MS4, or allows such a connection to continue. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-196. - Suspension of MS4 access. 
(a)  Suspension due to illegal discharges in emergency situations. The building official or his/her designee may, without prior notice, suspend MS4 discharge access to a person when such suspension is necessary to stop an actual or threatened discharge which presents or may present imminent and substantial danger to the environment, the health or welfare of persons, the MS4, or waters of the United States. If the violator fails to comply with a suspension order issued in an emergency, they may take such steps as deemed necessary to prevent or minimize damage to the MS4 or waters of the United States, or to minimize danger to persons. 
(b)  Suspension due to the detection of illegal discharge. Any person discharging into the MS4 in violation of this article may have their MS4 access terminated if such termination would abate or reduce an illegal discharge. The building official will notify a violator of the proposed termination of its MS4 access. The violator may petition the city council for a reconsideration and hearing. 
(c)  Reinstatement without permission. A person commits an offense if the person reinstates MS4 access to premises terminated pursuant to this section, without the prior approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-197. - Industrial or construction activity discharges. 
    Any person subject to an industrial or construction activity NPDES or TPDES storm water discharge permit shall comply with all provisions of such permit. Proof of compliance with said permit may be required in a form acceptable to the building official or his/her designee prior to allowing discharges to the MS4. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-198. - Submission of notice of intent to city. 
(a)  Notice of intent. The operator of a facility, including construction sites, required to have a NPDES or TPDES permit to discharge storm water associated with industrial activity shall submit a copy of the notice of intent (NOI) to the building official or his/her designee at the same time the operator submits the original notice of intent to the EPA or the TCEQ as applicable. The copy of the notice of intent may be delivered to the building official or his/her designee either in person or by mail. 
(b)  Offense for no notice of intent. A person commits an offense if the person operates a facility that is discharging storm water associated with industrial activity without having submitted a copy of the notice of intent to do so to the building official or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-199. - Monitoring of discharges. 
(a)  Applicability. This section applies to all facilities that have storm water discharges associated with industrial activity, including construction activity. 
(b)  Access to facilities. 
(1)  The building official or his/her designee shall be permitted to enter and inspect facilities subject to regulation under this article as often as may be necessary to determine compliance with this article. If a discharger has security measures in force which require proper identification and clearance before entry into its premises, the discharger shall make the necessary arrangements to allow access to representatives of the building official. 
(2)  Facility operators shall allow the building official or his/her designee ready access to all parts of the premises for the purposes of inspection, sampling, examination and copying of records that must be kept under the conditions of a NPDES or TPDES permit to discharge storm water, and the performance of any additional duties as defined by state and federal law. 
(3)  The building official or his/her designee shall have the right to set up on any permitted facility such devices as are necessary in the opinion of the building official to conduct monitoring and/or sampling of the facility's storm water discharge. 
(4)  The building official or his/her designee has the right to require the discharger to install monitoring equipment as necessary. The facility's sampling and monitoring equipment shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition by the discharger at its own expense. All devices used to measure storm water flow and quality shall be calibrated to ensure their accuracy. 
(5)  Any temporary or permanent obstruction to safe and easy access to the facility to be inspected and/or sampled shall be promptly removed by the operator at the written or oral request of the building official or his/her designee and shall not be replaced. The costs of clearing such access shall be borne by the operator. 
(6)  Unreasonable delays in allowing the building official or his/her designee access to a permitted facility is a violation of a storm water discharge permit and of this article. A person who is the operator of a facility with a NPDES or TPDES permit to discharge storm water associated with industrial activity commits an offense if the person denies the building official reasonable access to the permitted facility for the purpose of conducting any activity authorized or required by this article. 
(7)  If the building official or his/her designee has been refused access to any part of the premises from which storm water is discharged, and he/she is able to demonstrate probable cause to believe that there may be a violation of this article, or that there is a need to inspect and/or sample as part of a routine inspection and sampling program designed to verify compliance with this article or any order issued hereunder, or to protect the overall public health, safety, and welfare of the community, then the building official may seek issuance of a search warrant from any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-200. - Requirement to prevent, control, and reduce storm water pollutants by the use of best management practices. 
    The city adopts as identifying best management practices ("BMPs") for any activity, operation, or facility which may cause or contribute to pollution or contamination of storm water, the storm drainage system, or waters of the United States the Harris County Storm Water Management Handbook for Construction Activities, 2006 Edition, excluding Chapter 3, Chapter 5, and Appendix D. The owner or operator of a commercial or industrial establishment shall provide, at their own expense, reasonable protection from accidental discharge of prohibited materials or other wastes into the municipal storm drain system or watercourses through the use of these structural and non-structural BMPs. Further, any person responsible for a property or premise, which is, or may be, the source of an illegal discharge, may be required to implement, at said person's expense, additional structural and non-structural BMPs to prevent the further discharge of pollutants to the municipal separate storm sewer system. Compliance with all terms and conditions of a valid NPDES or TPDES permit authorizing the discharge of storm water associated with industrial activity, to the extent practicable, shall be deemed in compliance with the provisions of this section. These BMPs shall be part of a storm water pollution prevention plan (SWPPP) as necessary for compliance with requirements of the NPDES and/or TPDES permit. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-201. - Watercourse protection. 
    Every person who owns property, or is responsible for maintaining an easement through which a watercourse passes, or the lessee of such property, shall keep and maintain that part of the watercourse within the property free of trash, debris, excessive vegetation, and other obstacles that would pollute, contaminate, or significantly retard the flow of water through the watercourse. In addition, the property owner or lessee shall maintain existing privately owned structures within or adjacent to a watercourse so that such structures will not become a hazard to the use, function, or physical integrity of the watercourse. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-202. - Notification of spills. 
    Notwithstanding other requirements of law, as soon as any person responsible for a facility or operation, or responsible for emergency response for a facility or operation has information of any known or suspected release of materials which are resulting or may result in illegal discharges or pollutants discharging into storm water, the storm drainage system, or waters of the U.S., said person shall take all necessary steps to ensure the discovery, containment, and cleanup of such release. In the event of such a release of hazardous materials said person shall immediately notify emergency response agencies of the occurrence via emergency dispatch services. In the event of a release of non-hazardous materials said person shall notify the building official no later than the next business day. Notifications in person or by phone shall be confirmed by written notice addressed and mailed to the building official or his/her designee within three business days of the phone notice. If the discharge of prohibited materials emanates from a commercial or industrial establishment, the owner or operator of such establishment shall also retain an on-site written record of the discharge and the actions taken to prevent its recurrence. Such records shall be retained for at least three years. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-203. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Notice of violation. Whenever the building official or his/her designee finds that a person has violated a prohibition or failed to meet a requirement of this article, the building official may order compliance by written notice of violation to the responsible person. Such notice may require, without limitation: 
(1)  The performance of monitoring, analyses, and reporting; 
(2)  The elimination of illicit connections or discharges; 
(3)  That violating discharges, practices, or operations shall cease and desist; 
(4)  The abatement or remediation of storm water pollution or contamination hazards and the restoration of any affected property; 
(5)  Payment of a fine to cover administrative and remediation costs; and 
(6)  The implementation of source control or treatment BMPs. 
(b)  Remediation deadline. If abatement of a violation and/or restoration of affected property is required, the notice shall set forth a deadline within which such remediation or restoration must be completed. Said notice shall further advise that, should the violator fail to remediate or restore within the established deadline, the work will be done by a designated governmental agency or a contractor and the expense thereof shall be charged to the violator. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-204. - Appeal of notice of violation. 
    Any person receiving a notice of violation may appeal the determination of the building official to the city manager. The notice of appeal must be received within five business days from the date of the notice of violation. Hearing on the appeal before the city council shall take place within 15 business days from the date of receipt of the notice of appeal. The decision of the city council or their designee shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-205. - Enforcement measures after appeal. 
    If any violation of which a person has received notice as required by section 14-203 hereof has not been corrected pursuant to the requirements set forth in the notice of violation, or, in the event of an appeal, within ten business days of the decision of the city council upholding the decision, then the building official shall enter upon the subject private property and take any and all measures necessary to abate the violation and/or restore the property. It shall be unlawful for any person, owner, agent or person in possession of any premises to refuse to allow the building official or his/her designated contractor to enter upon the premises for the purposes set forth above. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-206. - Cost of abatement of the violation. 
    In the event of action by the building official as described in section 14-205, the owner of the property will be notified of the cost of abatement, including administrative costs, within 30 calendar days after the abatement of the violation. The property owner may file a written protest objecting to the amount of the assessment within ten business days. If the amount due is not paid within a timely manner as determined by the decision of the building official or his/her designee or by the expiration of the time in which to file an appeal, the charges shall become a special assessment against the property and shall constitute a lien on the property for the amount of the assessment. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the city by reason of such violation. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-207. - Injunctive relief. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this article. If a person has violated or continues to violate the provisions hereof, the building official may petition for a preliminary or permanent injunction restraining the person from activities that would create further violations or compelling the person to perform abatement or remediation of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-208. - Violations deemed a public nuisance. 
    In addition to the enforcement processes and penalties provided herein, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this article is deemed to be a threat to public health, safety and welfare and is declared to be a public nuisance. Consequently, any such public nuisance may be summarily abated or restored at the violator's expense and/or a civil action to abate, enjoin, or otherwise compel the cessation of such nuisance may be taken. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Secs. 14-209-14-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - POST-CONSTRUCTION CONTROLS ON NEW DEVELOPMENT AND SIGNIFICANT REDEVELOPMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 14-231. - Authority. 
    This article and the rules and regulations contained herein was adopted by the city council under authority of V.T.C.A., Water Code §§ 49.211, 51.122, 51.127 and 51.338, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-232. - Definitions. 
    Unless a provision explicitly states otherwise, the following terms and phrases, as used in this article, shall have the meanings hereinafter designated. 
    As-built certification means a form supplied and approved by the city's building department certifying that storm water quality features are completed and ready to use. 
    Certificate of compliance means a certificate issued by the city's building department indicating that a site complies with these regulations for storm water quality management as of a specific date. 
    Certificate of non-compliance means a certificate issued by the city's building department indicating a site does not comply with the regulations as of a specific date. The certificate also advises that legal action may be taken against the property owner. The certificate may be filed in the county real property records. 
    Certificate of proper operation means a form approved and provided by the city's building department for the purpose of certifying that the owner or operator of the storm water quality feature is complying with these regulations and its storm water quality management plan. 
    Industrial activity certification means a certificate approved by the city's building department that covers storm water discharges from new development and significant redevelopment at facilities that either has, or will have, permit coverage for storm water discharges associated with industrial activity under a permit issued by EPA or the TCEQ. 
    Non-exposure certification means a certificate approved by the city's building department that confirms that there is no exposure of individual material or activities to precipitation or runoff. To qualify for a non-exposure exclusion, facilities with storm water discharges associated with industrial activity shall submit to the city's building department a copy of a no exposure certification required to obtain coverage under the TCEQ multi-sector general permit. 
    Storm water discharges associated with industrial activity means the same as defined in Section 122.26(b)(14) of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, except that it shall not include discharges from the activities enumerated in subsection (x) of that section. 
    Storm water quality features means the devises or structures created using best management practices to eliminate or reduce pollution discharged into the MS4. 
    Storm water quality management plan or SWQMP means a plan prepared by an engineer licensed in this state in accordance with these regulations. 
    Storm water quality permit or SWQ permit means the permit issued by the city's building department indicating that the operator of a site or facilities has submitted and obtained approval of the necessary plans, and given the proper notices, as required by these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 42-2012, § 1, 11-19-12) 
Sec. 14-233. - Administration by building official.
