(2)  Playground equipment shall mean the equipment used in an outdoor area for recreation and play including, but not limited to, swing sets, slides, jungle gyms and sandlots. 
(3)  Swimming pool area shall mean the fenced in area where the swimming pool is located. This area shall be demarcated by the signs as authorized in (b) above. 
(4)  Smoking product shall mean variations of, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipes. 
(Ord. No. 003-97, § 2, 2-26-97) 
Sec. 54-42. - Tennis court footwear. 
    It shall be unlawful to wear shoes other than tennis shoes on the tennis court. 
(Ord. No. 012-97, 9-8-97) 
Secs. 54-43-54-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WESTWOOD DRIVE HIKE AND BIKE TRAIL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 78. 

Sec. 54-101. - Established. 
    The west side of Westwood Drive from its intersection with Robinson Road proceeding south to the Marylin Edgars City Park, including approximately the west four feet of the pavement of Westwood Drive, is designated and established by the city council as a pedestrian, wheelchair and bike pathway or trail (the "Westwood Drive Hike and Bike Trail"). All motorized vehicles are prohibited from traveling on or using the Westwood Drive Hike and Bike Trail, except vehicles which are permitted upon such area by the city in connection with the provision of city services, public utilities, and public emergency services. 
(Ord. No. 020-94, § 2, 12-14-94) 
Sec. 54-102. - No stopping, parking or standing. 
    The Westwood Drive Hike and Bike Trail is hereby designated as a "No Stopping, Parking, or Standing of Vehicles Zone." Accordingly, it shall be unlawful for any person to stop, park, or leave standing any vehicle, as those terms are defined by state law, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, as amended, whether attended or unattended, upon any part of the Westwood Drive Hike and Bike Trail. 
(Ord. No. 020-94, § 3, 12-14-94) 
Sec. 54-103. - Placement of signs. 
    The city manager and the chief of police are hereby jointly authorized and directed to place, or cause to be placed, appropriate striping, vehicle warning devices, and signs in accordance with the laws of the state giving notice that the Westwood Hike and Bike Trail is designated as a no vehicle stopping, parking, or standing zone. 
(Ord. No. 020-94, § 4, 12-14-94) 
Sec. 54-104. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person who intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly violates any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not to exceed $200.00 per offense. Each day any violation of this article shall continue, and each violation, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 020-94, § 5, 12-14-94) 
ARTICLE IV. - CHILD SEX OFFENDERS 

Sec. 54-105. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City park grounds or park facilities shall have the meaning defined in section 54-26 of the City of Oak Ridge North, Texas, Code of Ordinances. 
    Loiter means to linger aimlessly. 
    Child sex offender means a person who is a required to register as a sex offender under V.T.C.A., Code of Criminal Procedure ch. 62 or by any other local, state, or federal law who has been convicted or received an order of deferred adjudication for a sexual offense involving a minor. "Child sex offender" also shall mean a person who is a civilly committed sexually violent predator under V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code ch. 841. 
(Ord. No. 15-2015 , § 2, 5-27-15) 
Sec. 54-106. - Entry into city park grounds or park facilities or loitering outside city park grounds or park facilities; prohibited. 
    Except as allowed by section 54-106, 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for a child sex offender to enter a city park ground or park facility; or 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for a child sex offender to loiter within 300 feet outside a city park ground or park facility. 
(Ord. No. 15-2015 , § 2, 5-27-15) 
Sec. 54-107. - Exceptions. 
(a)  A child sex offender may enter a city park ground or park facility for the following purposes: 
(1)  To vote in an election, but such child sex offender may enter and remain in the city park ground or park facility only for as long as is necessary to complete the action of voting and shall vacate the city park ground or park facility immediately upon voting. The child sex offender shall only be in the portion of the city park ground or park facility where voting occurs and shall take the most direct route to and from such voting location; 
(2)  As authorized by a court order; 
(3)  In the event of a local, state, or federal declared emergency, a child sex offender may enter a city park ground or park facility when the park ground or park facility is used to house people in such emergency. The child sex offender shall notify the person in charge of the park ground or facility that he or she is a child sex offender upon entrance to the park ground or facility. The child sex offender shall only use the park ground or park facility as long as the declared emergency is in effect. 
(4)  By filing a written request for city park ground or park facility entrance with the city's police chief and being granted permission by the police chief to enter a city park ground or park facility. If the police chief denies the request to enter a city park ground or park facility, the child sex offender may appeal such denial to the city council by filing a written appeal with the city secretary no later than the 10 th day after the date of such denial. The city council shall hear such appeal no later than the 15 th day after the date the appeal is filed with the city secretary. The city council shall allow the child sex offender to speak and present evidence showing why he or she should be allowed to enter a city park ground or park facility. The city council shall allow any other persons present at the hearing to speak. The city council may call witnesses to testify, answer questions, or submit evidence at the hearing. The city council may limit speaking time by motion and majority vote of the city council present at the hearing. The city council shall either uphold the decision of the police chief or reverse the decision of the police chief. Such city council decision shall be rendered at the conclusion of the hearing; or 
(5)  If the child sex offender is denied city park ground or park facility entrance by the police chief and the reason the child sex offender desires to enter a city park ground or park facility would be rendered moot by the length of time it would take for city council to hear an appeal, then the city manager, mayor, and a city councilmember as selected by the mayor shall convene no later than 72 hours after the time the appeal is filed to hear the appeal. Such committee shall follow the procedures and timeframes as set forth in subsection (4) above. 
(Ord. No. 15-2015 , § 2, 5-27-15)

ARTICLE II. - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- The former article II, §§ 58-26-58-31, which pertained to the city zoning commission and derived from Ord. Chapter 62 - SIGNS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, adopted February 12, 2007, amended chapter 62, arts. I-X, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, chapter 62 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 018-99, § 2, adopted August 9, 1999, and Ord. No. 018-02, § 1, adopted November 25, 2002. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; businesses, ch. 18; planning, ch. 58; subdivisions, ch. 70; traffic and vehicles, ch. 78; traffic control devices, § 78-46 et seq.; zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of outdoor advertising of alcoholic beverages, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 108.55; regulation of signs by municipalities, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 216.001 et seq.; outdoor signs on rural roads, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6674-3; deceptive business practices, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 32.42. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Application. 
    This chapter applies to all signs within the corporate limits of the city and to off-premises freestanding signs located within the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 2-12-07) 
Sec. 62-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed thereto, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Abandoned sign shall mean a sign that advertises or directs persons to any business, commercial transaction or activity, goods, products or services that were once, but are no longer, offered, available, or located at the advertised premises. 
    Awning sign shall mean a sign constructed of fabric type material stretched over a rigid metal frame that is attached to the wall, or mansard of a building. Such sign shall be classified as a wall sign and counted as one of the three signs on a premise as established in this chapter. 
    Banner sign shall mean a sign constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric or other lightweight material, but not including portable signs, flags, light standard decorations or awning signs. 
    Cabinet shall mean that portion of a sign structure containing the advertising display of a single commercial or business enterprise. 
    Commercial message shall mean speech contained on a sign that advertises or calls attention to a business, product, service or other commercial activity conducted for profit. 
    Commercial sign shall mean a sign that contains a commercial message. 
    Electrical sign shall mean any sign containing electrical wiring or utilizing electric current, but not including signs illuminated by an exterior source. 
    Extraterritorial jurisdiction (ETJ) shall mean that portion of unincorporated territory extending one-half mile beyond and contiguous to the city's corporate boundaries that is not included within the corporate boundaries or extraterritorial jurisdiction of another municipality. 
    Freestanding sign shall mean a permanent sign mounted on the ground and supported by one or more columns, poles, uprights, or braces anchored in or on the ground and not attached to any building. 
    Holiday decoration shall mean a temporary display erected on a seasonal basis, in observance of a religious, national or state holiday, and which contains no commercial message. 
    Logo shall mean any pictorial symbol, device or other visual representation commonly utilized by, and associated with, any commercial business or commercial service entity as a means of identifying or advertising such entity. 
    Lot shall mean a tract or parcel of land having boundaries established by legal instrument, such as a recorded deed or plat, and which is recognized as a separate unit of real property for purposes of transferring title. For the purposes of this chapter, contiguous lots, or portions thereof, upon which a single principal building and its accessory buildings are located, shall be deemed as one lot. 
    Marquee sign shall mean a sign attached to, or which constitutes an integral part of, a canopy or permanently covered structure, projecting from and supported by a structural frame or vertical pipe supports extending beyond a building. 
    Message board or menu board shall mean a sign or portion of a sign designed to allow the manual removal or replacement of individual letters, words or symbols on the sign face for the purpose of changing a message. 
    Multi-tenant sign shall mean a commercial on-premise sign for two or more separate commercial businesses or commercial service entities upon a single sign structure. 
    Non-commercial sign shall mean a sign containing a noncommercial message. 
    Non-commercial message shall mean a civic, political, religious, seasonal, personal or other message not containing any commercial message, not displayed for a fee or for compensation, and located on property owned or lawfully occupied by the person displaying the message. 
    Off-premise sign shall mean a sign that directs attention to a business, person, activity, goods, products, or services not usually located on the property where the sign is located, or which directs persons to a location other than the property where the sign is located. 
    On-premise sign shall mean a sign that directs attention to a business, person, activity, goods, product, or service offered on the same property on which the sign is located. 
    Operating permit shall mean a decal, tag, or placard issued by the sign administrator, attached to a sign structure as designated by the sign administrator, signifying compliance with this chapter. 
    Portable sign shall mean a sign designed and constructed for easy movement from one location to another, including a sign mounted upon or designed to be mounted upon trailers, wheeled carriers, or other nonmotorized mobile structures. A portable sign that has its wheels removed shall still be deemed a portable sign. 
    Projecting sign shall mean any sign that is affixed to any building wall or structure and extends beyond the building wall or structure more than 12 inches. 
    Provisional sign shall mean a sign of lightweight material to be used until permanent signage can be fabricated and erected. 
    Roof sign shall mean any sign or portion of a sign erected, constructed or maintained above the roofline of any building. 
    Shingle sign shall mean a sign having a sign face no greater than one and one-half square feet in size, and which is located adjacent to the main entrance door to a business or business suite. 
    Sign administrator shall mean the city manager or his designed representative. 
    Spectacular sign shall mean a sign that has one or more of the following as elements in its physical structure: 
(1)  Automatically changing message that occurs more often than once every five minutes; 
(2)  Blinking, rotating, moving, chasing, flashing, glaring, strobe, scintillating or spot lights, or similar devices; 
(3)  Lights or colored elements creating a continuously moving, shimmering or prismatic effect; or 
(4)  Rotating or moving parts. 
    Premises shall mean: 
(1)  For developed property, the area of real property that encompasses all the buildings, structures, appurtenances and contiguous land devoted to a common use and not separated by a public street, such as a shopping center; or 
(2)  For undeveloped property, the area of real property designated as a lot on a plat approved in accordance with law and filed with the county clerk's office, or an unplatted tract of land as conveyed by deed or operation of law and recorded in the deed records of the county. 
    Sign shall mean any structure, fixture, placard, or device, or part thereof, or inscription, which is located upon, attached to, or painted or represented on any land, or on the outside of any building or structure, or on an awning, canopy, marquee, or similar appendage, or affixed to glass on the exterior of a building or structure, and which displays or includes any numeral, letter, word, model, banner, emblem, insignia, symbol, device, monogram, heraldry, trademark, light, or other representation used as or in the nature of an announcement, advertisement, attention arrester, direction, warning, or designation of any person, firm, group, organization, corporation, association, place, commodity, product, service, business establishment, profession, enterprise, industry, activity, or any combination thereof. Where the word sign is used herein without further modification, the same shall be understood to embrace all regulated signs and replicas. 
    Sign area shall mean the total square footage of all sign facing, including that portion of the supporting structure or trim which carries any wording, symbols, or pictures; provided however, in the case of double-faced signs, only one face shall be computed to determine sign area; provided further however, in the case of multifaced signs, all faces shall be computed to determine sign area. 
    Sign face shall mean that portion of a sign structure upon, against, or through which the message is displayed or illustrated; provided however, for signs in which the words, letters, or symbols are independently mounted, the sign facing shall mean the smallest regular geometric form containing all of the individual words, letters, and symbols. However, if there is background in addition to the lettering, background material shall be included if the background is uniquely associated with the letters. 
    Sign structure shall mean any structure that supports or is capable of supporting a sign or any number of sign cabinets. A sign structure may be a single pole or multiple poles and may or may not be an integral part of a building. 
    Stake sign shall mean a sign constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric, paper, cardboard, wallboard, or other light materials with short life expectancies, mounted on a stake, rod, or other similar supporting structure attached to the ground. A stake sign shall not be considered a portable sign. 
    Temporary sign shall mean a sign constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric, papers, cardboard, wallboard, or other light material and shall include all types of temporary attention attracting devices or displays. 
    Visibility triangle shall mean the triangular area adjacent to the intersection of any public streets or any other type roadway within which sight lines are required to be maintained for vehicular traffic. The triangle is established by measuring a distance of 45 feet from the intersection of the street or roadway right-of-way. A straight line connecting the ends of each measured distance that forms the hypotenuse shall establish the visibility triangle. 
    Wall sign shall mean a sign painted on or attached to the exterior of a building, and extending not more than six inches from an exterior wall in a parallel manner. 
    Wind device sign means any flag, pennant, streamer, balloon or similar sign made of cloth, canvas, plastic or other flexible material, with or without a frame or other supporting structure, that moves or is designed or intended to move or blow in the wind. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 2-12-07; Ord. No. 28-2012, § 2, 7-9-12) 
Sec. 62-3. - Exemptions. 
    The following signs shall be exempt from all regulations under this chapter other than section 62-4: 
(1)  Government signs. Government signs and any sign containing an official or public notice or warning required by any law, rule, regulation, ordinance, or order of any federal, state or local government or agency thereof, or any court of competent jurisdiction; 
(2)  Private traffic signs. Signs on private property containing no advertising that direct the movement of traffic, warn of obstacles or overhead clearances, or control parking, including entrance and exit signs; 
(3)  Railway signs. Signs on railway property that pertain to the operation of the railroad, and which are placed and maintained by or under the authority and control of the railway company owning or operating the railway property; 
(4)  Public utility signs. Signs marking utility or underground communication or transmission lines and hazards when required or authorized by the governmental entity having jurisdiction over the utility company placing such sign; 
(5)  Plaques. Historical and commemorative plaques placed by historical societies or other organizations recognized as such by applicable state, local or federal agencies, if such signs are less than 15 square feet in sign area; 
(6)  Mailboxes and addresses. Addresses and names located on mailboxes; 
(7)  Vehicle signs. Signs displayed or used upon vehicles and trailers, unless the vehicle or trailer is permanently stationed or regularly used at a fixed location to serve the same or similar purpose of a permanent or portable sign; 
(8)  Athletic field signs. Signs located on the field side of scoreboards and fences of athletic fields; 
(9)  National or state flags. National and/or state flags provided that the size of the flag(s) does not exceed the total allowable sign area for freestanding signs for that premises if within a non-single family residential zone, or in excess of 36 square feet if within a single-family residential zone; 
(10)  Signs not visible from street. Any sign not visible from a public or private street; 
(11)  Holiday decorations; 
(12)  Signs on persons or animals. Hand-held signs on persons or animals; 
(13)  Unused signs. Signs being manufactured or in transport and not being used for advertising; 
(14)  Signs on outdoor machines, devices, and equipment. Signs located on outdoor machines, devices or equipment which display the trademark, trade name, manufacturer, cost, or operating or service instructions or similar information but do not advertise the business where located. This exemption includes Signs on coin-operated vending machines, fuel-dispensing pumps, telephone facilities, automatic teller machines, automotive vacuum cleaners, amusement rides, and similar machines, devices, or equipment. 
(15)  Windows and door signs. Signs painted on or placed on and supported by the glass surfaces of windows or doors, if not visible from a public street. 
(16)  Non-commercial signs. 
(17)  Wall signs. Signs less than 35 square feet in sign area painted on exterior walls. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 2-12-07) 
Sec. 62-4. - Prohibited signs. 
    Except as otherwise specifically authorized herein, it shall be unlawful for any person to erect, install, construct, display, maintain, reconstruct, place, locate, relocate or use of any of the following: 
(1)  Spectacular signs; 
(2)  Portable signs; 
(3)  Signs located on a roof or attached to a building if it projects above the highest point of the facade or parapet; 
(4)  Signs that are deteriorated, dilapidated, or unsafe; 
(5)  Signs located on or attached to a streetlight, utility pole, hydrant, bridge, traffic-control device, street sign, or other city-owned building, facility, structure, or equipment, or within or upon any public street, public roadway right-of-way or public easement without consent of the city; 
(6)  Signs that do not comply with this chapter or any other applicable rule, regulation, or ordinance of the city; 
(7)  Signs located on trees or shrubs; 
(8)  Signs located or illuminated so that they obscure or interfere with the effectiveness of an official traffic sign, signal, or device, or obstruct or interfere with the view of approaching, emerging or intersecting traffic, or prevent any traveler on any street from obtaining a clear view of approaching vehicles; 
(9)  Signs, illuminated from within or without, that: 
a.  Are illuminated to such intensity or without proper shielding so as to constitute a hazard to the operation of motor vehicles upon a public or private street, or substantially interfere with the reasonable enjoyment of residential property, or cast glare upon adjacent residential property; or 
b.  Have any type of intermittent illumination, including flashing, fading, revolving or blinking lights, or any type of moving, traveling or changing message by means of lights or illumination; 
(10)  Any sign that violates any sight visibility regulations of the city; 
(11)  Off-premises signs; 
(12)  A sign located on any railroad right-of-way that is not used for or related to railroad operations; and 
(13)  Any sign that, due to its location or maintenance, creates a hazard to vehicular or pedestrian safety, impedes the ability of the city or other applicable entity to provide emergency services, or impedes emergency evacuations by any persons from any building or structure; and 
(14)  Wind device signs. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 2-12-07) 
Sec. 62-5. - Manner of measurement. 
(a)  Setback. The setback of a sign structure is measured perpendicularly from the right-of-way line to the closest point of any part of the sign structure. 
(b)  Height. The height of a sign structure is measured from the natural ground level at the base of the sign structure to the highest point of the sign structure. 
(c)  Width. The width of a sign structure is measured along a line drawn from the outermost edges of the sign structure, parallel to the ground. 
(d)  Sign area. The sign area shall be as defined herein. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 2-12-07) 
Sec. 62-6. - Conflicts. 
    In the event of conflict between any provision of this chapter and the zoning ordinance of the city, the zoning ordinance shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 2-12-07) 
Secs. 62-7-62-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 62-11. - Permit requirements; exemptions. 
(a)  Permits generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, locate, relocate, erect, construct, replace or alter the size or shape of any part of a freestanding sign or wall sign, including the face or other integral part, or to thereafter make use of a freestanding sign or wall sign without having first secured a sign permit from the city, except as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(b)  Exemptions. A sign permit shall not be required for the following: 
(1)  Changing the advertising copy or message of a painted sign; 
(2)  Periodically changing of letters, numbers or the message portion of a lawful sign specifically designed for that purpose; 
(3)  Performing routine electrical, painting, and cleaning maintenance and repair of a sign. 
(4)  Signs painted on glass surfaces or windows or doors not larger than 35 square feet in sign area. 
(5)  Signs painted directly upon the wall of a building not larger than 35 square feet or less in sign area; however, such signs shall be counted as wall signs. 
(6)  Shingle signs. 
(7)  Wall signs attached to the wall of a building having a sign face of six square feet or less. 
(8)  Message boards or menu boards at food establishments, theaters, and similar establishments that contain a sign face of 35 square feet or less in size and eight feet or less in height, provided such messages and prices are contained within an enclosed sign face. 
(9)  Signs attached to fences having a sign face of four square feet or less, giving notice, instructions, or warning of contents enclosed by the fence, but not containing commercial messages. 
(10)-(13)  Reserved. 
(14)  One temporary contractor's identification sign, not exceeding 35 square feet in sign area, during the time such repair or construction activity is being conducted. Such sign shall include contractor identification information only, and shall not include any advertisement of products or services. 
(15)  a.  A business may erect two grand opening banner signs which are attached to the building's exterior facade on the exterior facade facing a street. If the building only has street frontage on one side, then only one grand opening banner sign is allowed. Grand opening banner signs may be erected for no more than 30 days, which days must be consecutive. Grand opening banner signs may be displayed to advertise the business before it opens. 
b.  In addition to the allowed grand opening banner signs in subsection a., a business also may erect three special event banner signs during a calendar year. Only one special event banner sign may be attached to the building's exterior facade at a time. Banners may not be erected for more than 14 days, which days must be consecutive. 
c.  All banner signs must be attached securely and placed flush against the building's exterior facade. 
d.  All banners sign must be registered and approved by the city's sign administrator. 
(16)  On-premise directional signs, not exceeding six square feet in sign area or 42 inches in height, provided such signs display only business names or logos, the location of or directions to parking or buildings located on the premises, or regulating the flow of on-premise traffic. Directional signs shall be limited to one per entrance or exit used for vehicular access to or from the business premises, and such additional number as many be required for parking lot traffic control. Such signs shall not project into public right-of-way, shall not obstruct any sidewalk, and shall not be placed so as to create hazards to pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(17)  Signs required by the Texas Accessibility Standards (TAS) for disabled persons, provided such signs are in full compliance with the TAS requirements. 
(18)  Signs displayed upon motor vehicles; provided, however, any sign displayed upon a motor vehicle primarily for the purpose of advertising is not exempted from the provisions of this chapter, and use such vehicle signs are prohibited. 
(19)  Marquee signs not exceeding 40 square feet in sign area, that are mounted no higher than the roof line, that form an integral part of a canopy or marquee entrance, and that state only the street number, name of the proprietor and the name of the premises therein. The marquee sign shall not display advertisement for goods or services. The number of such signs shall not exceed the number of pedestrian entrances for such premises. Such signs shall be counted as marquee signs for purposes of this sign count for a business or premises as set out in this chapter. 
(20)  Provisional signs installed by a registered licensed sign contractor holding current and valid permits for the erection of permanent signage on the location where the provisional signs are erected. The number of provisional signs shall not exceed the number of permanent signs for which permits have been issued, and all provisional signs shall be removed within ten days following final installation of the approved permanent signs. 
(21)  Signs on newspaper vending machines. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 2-12-07; Ord. No. 28-2012, § 3, 7-9-12) 
Sec. 62-12. - Application/permits. 
    Applications for sign permits and applicable fees shall be submitted on forms provided by the city and shall be accompanied by information, drawings and descriptive data required to ensure proper regulation of the sign and to ensure compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Any ground sign exceeding 30 feet in height above natural ground level, and every roof sign of any height or size, shall require drawings and data of the sign and sign structure prepared and certified by a professional engineer registered in the state. If certification of plans to assure public safety is warranted, the applicant shall have the plans and data sealed, signed and dated by a registered professional engineer, registered in the state. 
(1)  New signs-Construction. Every new sign shall be inspected at least once during or after construction. If the sign meets all conditions and specifications of this chapter and the sign construction permit, an operating permit shall be issued. If the sign does not conform, the applicant shall have 30 days in which to bring the sign into compliance. If not in compliance after such 30-day period, the sign, including sign structure, shall be removed. 
(2)  Operating permit, expiration and renewal. Each operating permit issued shall be effective for a period of three (3) years. Not less than 30 days nor more than 60 days prior to the expiration of each three-year period, application may be made for a three-year extension of the operating permit. Each application, whether original or renewal, shall be accompanied by the payment of applicable fees as established from time to time by the city. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 2-12-07) 
Sec. 62-13. - Permits; issuance. 
    If the application for a permit hereunder shows compliance with the requirements of this chapter and other city regulations, the administering employee shall issue the appropriate permit. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 2-12-07) 
Sec. 62-14. - Duration. 
    Unless earlier revoked, a sign permit to construct, erect or place a freestanding sign or a wall sign shall be valid for 180 days from the date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 2-12-07) 
Sec. 62-15. - Revocation. 
    A sign permit may be revoked for a violation of this chapter. The administering employee shall give prior written notice of a proposed revocation to the permittee and an opportunity to respond to the reasons for revocation prior to making a decision thereon. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 2-12-07) 
Sec. 62-16. - Variance. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by the provisions of this chapter may submit a variance application to the city and pay a variance fee as set forth by the city council in a schedule of fees. The application shall include the reason for the variance request and the hardship suffered by the applicant because of the rules and regulations contained herein. 
(b)  The city council shall hear all variance requests within 30 days of the application and fee being filed with the city. 
(c)  The city council may grant a variance, deny a variance, or reset the hearing to obtain more information. If the city council resets the hearing, the subsequent hearing shall occur no later than the 30th day after the date of the first hearing unless the requested information cannot be obtained in that time in which case the city council may reset the hearing to any reasonable date in the future. If the city council does not reset the hearing or if it resets a hearing and receives all requested information, then the city council shall grant or deny the variance request no later than the 20th day after the date of the hearing. 
(d)  In grating a variance, the city council may impose such conditions it deems necessary to ensure the public health, safety, and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 28-2012, § 4, 7-9-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 28-2012, § 4, adopted July 9, 2012, repealed and reenacted section 62-16 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, section 62-16 pertained to appeals, and derived from Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, adopted February 12, 2007. 
Secs. 62-17-62-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REGULATIONS 

Sec. 62-23. - Regulatory scheme. 
(a)  For purposes of applying these regulations, all permitted signs are defined and classified, according to their physical characteristics, as follows: 
(1)  Freestanding signs; 
(2)  Wall signs; and 
(3)  Stake signs. 
(b)  Freestanding signs and wall signs, due to their physical characteristics, are considered permanent Signs, designed for use for extended periods of time. Stake signs, due to their physical characteristics, are considered temporary signs, designed for use for isolate individual events, such as elections, garage sales, grand openings, etc. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 2-12-07) 
_____
Sec. 62-24. - Freestanding signs. 
(a)  Table of regulations. Except as otherwise provided in this section, freestanding signs shall comply with the requirements of the following table:
